The '''Agricultural & Applied Economics Association''' ('''AAEA''') is a professional association for those interested in the field of [[Agricultural economics|agricultural]] and [[applied economics]].
Established in 1910, AAEA currently has more than 2,500 members in more than 20 countries. Members of AAEA work in academic or government institutions as well as in industry and not-for-profit organizations, and engage in a variety of research, teaching, and outreach activities in the areas of agriculture, the environment, food, health, and international development.
==Publications == AAEA is responsible for two journals, the ''[[American Journal of Agricultural Economics]]'' (''AJAE''),<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.aaea.org/publications/ajae/ |title=Archived copy |access-date=2009-05-05 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090421220540/http://www.aaea.org/publications/ajae/ |archive-date=2009-04-21 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref> and the ''[[Applied Economic Perspectives and Policy]]'' (''AEPP''),<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.aaea.org/publications/aepp/|title=AEPP - Agricultural & Applied Economics Association|website=Aaea.org|accessdate=14 August 2018}}</ref> both of which are published by [[Oxford University Press]]. The association also publishes two [[outreach]] publications, an online policy magazine called [[Choices Magazine|''Choices'']] and a bi-monthly newsletter for its members called ''The Exchange''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.aaea.org/publications/exchange/|title=The Exchange - Agricultural & Applied Economics Association|website=Aaea.org|accessdate=14 August 2018}}</ref>
==History== AAEA was founded in 1910 as the American Farm Management Association. In 1919, it merged with the American Association of Agricultural Economists to form the American Farm Economic Association (AFEA). The ''Journal of Farm Economics'' was first published in 1919 as well.
In 1968, the AFEA changed its name to the American Agricultural Economics Association (AAEA), at which point its journal became the ''American Journal of Agricultural Economics''. Finally, in 2008, AAEA changed its name to the Agricultural & Applied Economics Association, in order to more accurately describe its membership and the broadening focus of the Association.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.aaea.org/UserFiles/file/Association_Name_Change.pdf|format=PDF|title=We are pleased to announce that effective August 1, 2008, that is directly after the 2008 Joint Annual Meeting in Orlando, Florida, our Association name will be changed to the Agricultural and Applied Economics Association (AAEA)|website=Aaea.org|accessdate=14 August 2018}}</ref>
==John K. Galbraith Forum and Award== The '''John Kenneth Galbraith Forum and Award''' is awarded annually. This prestigious honor goes to a distinguished professional for continuing Galbraith's tradition of outstanding research and major social contributions. The Galbraith Award winner is also a plenary speaker at the AAEA Annual Meeting.
John Kenneth Galbraith was born October 15, 1908. He received his Ph.D. in agricultural economics from the University of California, Berkeley. After graduation, he taught at Berkeley and the University of California, Davis. Galbraith then moved to the East Coast and had a long and distinguished career teaching economics at Harvard and Princeton Universities. He has played an important public service and policy role. During World War II Galbraith administered price controls for the United States. He was an adviser to multiple U.S. Presidents and served as U.S. Ambassador to India under President John F. Kennedy. Galbraith also served as the editor of ''Fortune Magazine'' from 1943-1948, and a wrote several books including ''American Capitalism'' (1951) and ''The Affluent Society'' (1958). He holds the Medal of Freedom and the Order of Canada.
The Forum was created in 2003 as an honor to Galbraith. Agricultural and applied economists from around the world gathered at the 2003 AAEA annual meeting in Montreal, Canada, to witness the birth of the John Kenneth Galbraith Forum and Award. The Galbraith Fund was established within the AAEA Trust by private donors. The Galbraith Forum and Award Committee selects the recipient of the Award each year. The committee has six members appointed to a three-year rotating term, with two new members each year. Five Galbraith Award Honorees are Nobel Laureates.
=== Past recipients === ''* indicates Nobel Laureate''
* 2003: Gordon Rausser, University California, Berkeley, James Galbraith, University of Texas, Derek Bok, Harvard University * 2004: Joseph E. Stiglitz*, Columbia University * 2005: Michael E. Porter, Harvard University * 2006: Kenneth Arrow*, Stanford Institute for Economic Policy * 2007: Sir Partha Dasgupta, St. John’s College, Cambridge * 2008: Elinor Ostrom*, Indiana University * 2009: Angus Deaton*, Princeton University * 2010: John A. List, University of Chicago * 2011: Martin Ravallion, World Bank * 2012: Daron Acemoglu, Massachusetts Institute of Technology * 2013: Martin Weitzman, Harvard University * 2014: Jean Tirole*, Toulouse School of Economics * 2015: Anne Case, Princeton University * 2016: Alain de Janvry, University of California, Berkeley

Business executive | known_for = }} '''Alexander Ivanovich Kazakov''' ({{lang-ru|Александр Иванович Казаков}}; born 24 May 1948, [[Moscow]]) is a [[Russian people|Russian]] politician and economist who held a number of senior government posts during the [[Presidency of Boris Yeltsin|presidency]] of [[Boris Yeltsin]], including deputy chief of the [[Presidential Administration of Russia|presidential administration]] and [[Deputy Prime Minister of Russia|Deputy Prime Minister]]. He was among the officials in charge of overseeing the [[privatization in Russia|privatization of the Russian economy]] in the 1990s, being the head of the [[State Property Committee]]. Kazakov was also an associate of [[Anatoly Chubais]]. ==Biography== Under the [[Soviet Union]], Kazakov worked in [[Gosplan]], the economic planning agency of the USSR, until 1992.[http://www.upi.com/Archives/1996/01/25/Yeltsin-names-new-privatization-chief/5246822546000/ Yeltsin names new privatization chief]. [[UPI]]. Published 25 January 1996. Retrieved 6 September 2017. During his service in the Russian government, Kazakov was deputy chairman of the property commission under [[Anatoly Chubais]] in 1993–1994 before becoming part of [[President of Russia|President]] [[Boris Yeltsin]]'s administration as the head of the department working with regional bureaucracies.Zhigulsky, Anton (27 January 1996). [http://old.themoscowtimes.com/sitemap/free/1996/1/article/gki-chief-kazakov-a-chubais-man/329256.html GKI Chief Kazakov 'A Chubais Man']. ''[[The Moscow Times]]''. Retrieved 6 September 2017. In January 1996, President Yeltsin appointed Kazakov to the post of chairman of the [[State Property Committee]] and also one of the [[Deputy Prime Minister of Russia|Deputy Chairmen of Government of the Russian Federation]].Krichevsky, Grigory (9 January 1996). [https://www.rferl.org/a/1079978.html Yeltsin Names Key Officials To Oversee Economic Reforms]. [[Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty]]. Retrieved 6 September 2017. In his new position, Kazakov was largely carrying out the policies favored by Chubais, being expected to continue them rather than make major changes. He also worked as an official at [[Gazprom]] during the 1990s.[[#Böhme2011|Böhme (2011)]], p. 67 ==Sources== ===References=== {{reflist}} ===Books=== * {{cite book |last1 = Böhme |first1 = Dimo |title = EU-Russia Energy Relations: What Chance for Solutions? Focus on the Natural Gas Sector |publisher = [[University of Potsdam]] |location = |year = 2011 |isbn = 978-3869561202 |url = |ref = Böhme2011 }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Kazakov, Alexander}} [[Category:1948 births]] [[Category:20th-century Russian politicians]] [[Category:Deputy heads of government of the Russian Federation]] [[Category:Gazprom people]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Members of the Federation Council (Russia)]] [[Category:Russian economists]] [[Category:Russian businesspeople]]

[[File:Alfredo Fortabat.JPG|thumb|210px|Alfredo Fortabat]] '''Alfredo Fortabat''' (1894 – January 19, 1976) was a prominent Argentine industrialist.
==Life and times== Alfredo Fortabat was born in [[Azul, Buenos Aires|Azul]], a small city in [[Buenos Aires Province]], in 1894; his parents, Helene Pourtal and Lucien Fortabat, were recently arrived [[French Argentine]]s. Lucien Fortabat was named Director of Azul's important French language school and later Director of the ''Banco Comercial'', which enabled his son, Alfredo, to attend the [[University of Paris|Sorbonne]]. The elder Fortabat died in 1921, however, and upon Alfredo's return in 1924, local [[cement kiln]] owners encouraged him to invest in the growing industry.<ref name=rn>[http://www.rionegro.com.ar/suple_economico/05-04-30/nota2.php ''Río Negro'': La trama de la venta del grupo Fortabat {{es icon}}]</ref>
The 1926 discovery of large [[limestone]] deposits at the San Jacinto Estancia inherited from his father led Fortabat to open a cement factory in the nearby [[pampas]] hamlet of Loma Negra (south of [[Olavarría]]); the choice of location prompted him to christen the company ''[[Loma Negra]]'' (''"Black Mound"''). The cement plant was built in 1927, and Fortabat protected his venture in its early years partly by buying voting shares in competitors' boards.<ref name=rn/><ref name=loma>[http://www.lomanegra.com.ar/index_loma.htm Loma Negra: historia {{es icon}}] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090801052352/http://www.lomanegra.com.ar/index_loma.htm |date=2009-08-01 }}</ref>
Fortabat, whose marriage to Magdalena Corti Maderna ended in divorce, met a young [[Buenos Aires]] heiress, [[María Amalia Lacroze de Fortabat|Amalia Lacroze]], during a 1941 [[Teatro Colón]] function, and the two began a relationship. Planning to wed, they were impeded by Argentina's then-conservative nuptial laws, which precluded separated couples from remarrying. The marriage, which ultimately took place in neighboring [[Uruguay]], became recognized in Argentina following a reform signed into law by President [[Juan Perón]], in 1951. Mrs. Fortabat's gregariousness and knowledge of four foreign languages helped create a close business partnership as well as marriage, though it later suffered from a number of publicly reported infidelities.<ref name=actual>[http://www.articlearchives.com/south-america/argentina-buenos-aires-argentina/447105-1.html Colín, Julia. "Amalia Lacroze de Fortabat." ''Actual'' (6/1/1999) {{es icon}}] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090612050224/http://www.articlearchives.com/south-america/argentina-buenos-aires-argentina/447105-1.html |date=2009-06-12 }}</ref>
Loma Negra grew alongside the [[Argentine economy]]; by the early 1950s, the company produced 500,000 tons of cement annually and accounted for 70% of the cement sold to the Ministry of Public Works, for instance (his prominence as a building materials supplier during the Perón years triggered investigations against Loma Negra following the populist leader's 1955 overthrow, though charges were later dropped).<ref name=rn/> New facilities in the [[Andes]]-range cities of [[San Juan, Argentina|San Juan]] and [[Zapala]], opened during the 1960s, made Loma Negra the leader in cement and concrete production nationally.<ref name=loma/>
The industrialist invested generously in employee housing and in 1930, established a largely self-contained community adjacent the cement works ("Villa Alfredo Fortabat").<ref name=loma/> The proprietor of 160,000 hectares (400,000 acres) of prime [[pampas]] land in his later years, he established the charitable Amalia Lacroze de Fortabat Foundation, in 1971.<ref name=rn/>
Alfredo Fortabat died in Buenos Aires on January 19, 1976, upon which his widow became the President and nearly sole owner of [[Loma Negra]].

{{marriage|[[Melanie Griffith]]
|1996|2015|end=divorced}} }} '''José Antonio Domínguez Bandera''' (born 10 August 1960), known professionally as '''Antonio Banderas''', is a Spanish actor, producer, and singer. He began his acting career with a series of films by director [[Pedro Almodóvar]] and then appeared in high-profile [[Hollywood]] films, especially in the 1990s, including ''[[Assassins (film)|Assassins]]'', ''[[Evita (1996 film)|Evita]]'', ''[[Interview with the Vampire (film)|Interview with the Vampire]]'', ''[[Philadelphia (film)|Philadelphia]]'', ''[[Desperado (film)|Desperado]]'', ''[[The Mask of Zorro]]'', ''[[Take the Lead]]'', ''[[The Expendables 3]]'' and ''[[Spy Kids]]''. Banderas also provided the voice of [[Puss in Boots (Shrek)|Puss in Boots]] in the [[Shrek (franchise)|''Shrek'' series]] and its spin-off film ''[[Puss in Boots (2011 film)|Puss in Boots]]'' as well as the bee in the U.S. [[Mometasone furoate|Nasonex]] commercials. == Early life == Banderas{{cite journal|title=Two Hispanics in the 2005 Hollywood 'Walk of Fame'|journal=Hispanic Almanac|date=2005|page=202|url=https://books.google.com/?id=hidZAAAAYAAJ&q=%22Bandera%22|accessdate=20 June 2017|publisher=Hispanic Publishing Group|quote=Antonio Banderas (actor) was born Jose Antonio Dominguez Bandera in Malaga, Spain, on August 10, 1960.}} was born on 10 August 1960, in the [[Andalusia]]n city of [[Málaga]], to José Domínguez Prieto (1920-2008), a police officer in the [[Civil Guard (Spain)|Civil Guard]], and Ana Bandera Gallego (1933-2017), a school teacher.{{cite web|url=http://www.filmreference.com/film/52/Antonio-Banderas.html|title=Antonio Banderas Biography (1960 - ) |publisher= FilmReference.com|date=|accessdate=17 February 2010| quote=[M]arried Ana Leza (an actress), c. 1986 (some sources cite 1988; divorced, 1996)}}{{cite web|url=http://www.elmundo.es/magazine/m53/textos/avances.html |title=The mother of ... Antonio Banderas |work=[[El Mundo (Spain)|El Mundo]] |location=Spain |date=n.d. |accessdate=26 March 2017 |archivedate=18 October 2000 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20001018001656/http://www.elmundo.es/magazine/m53/textos/avances.html |deadurl=no |quote=Ana Banderas Gallego [es la madre de] José Antonio Domínguez Banderas.... Ha sido profesora de educación primaria en distintos colegios. Casada con José Domínguez Prieto, es madre de dos hijos: Antonio y Francisco Javier. / Ana Banderas Gallego [is the mother of] José Antonio Domínguez Banderas.... She has been a teacher of primary education in different schools. ... Married to José Domínguez Prieto, she is the mother of two children: Antonio and Francisco Javier. }} He has a brother, Francisco Javier. Although his father's family name is Domínguez, he took his mother's last name as his stage name.{{cite web|url=http://www.salon.com/ent/col/srag/1999/09/23/shelton/print.html|title=Salon Column | Ron "The Artist" Shelton|publisher=Salon.com|date=|accessdate=17 February 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080919091323/http://www.salon.com/ent/col/srag/1999/09/23/shelton/print.html| archivedate=19 September 2008| deadurl= no}} As a child, he wanted to become a professional football player until a broken foot sidelined his dreams at the age of fourteen. He showed a strong interest in the performing arts and formed part of the ARA Theatre-School run by Ángeles Rubio-Argüelles y Alessandri (wife of diplomat, writer and film director [[Edgar Neville]]) and the College of Dramatic Art, both in [[Málaga]]. His work in the theater, and his performances on the streets, eventually landed him a spot with the Spanish National Theatre.{{cite web|url=http://www.starpulse.com/Actors/Banderas,_Antonio/Biography/ |title=Antonio Banderas Biography |publisher=StarPulse.com |accessdate=8 June 2011 |archivedate=22 December 2015 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151222162026/http://www.starpulse.com/Actors/Banderas%2C_Antonio/Biography/ |deadurl=yes }} == Career == === Early work, 1982–1990 === Banderas began working in small shops during [[Spain]]'s post-dictatorial cultural movement known as the [[La Movida Madrileña]]. While performing with the theatre, Banderas caught the attention of Spanish director [[Pedro Almodóvar]], who cast the young actor in his 1982 movie debut ''[[Labyrinth of Passion]]''. Five years later, he went on to appear in the director's ''[[Law of Desire]]'', making headlines with his performance as a [[gay]] man, which required him to engage in his first male-to-male onscreen kiss. After Banderas appeared in Almodóvar's 1986 ''[[Matador (film)|Matador]]'', the director cast him in his internationally acclaimed 1988 film, ''[[Women on the Verge of a Nervous Breakdown]]''. The recognition Banderas gained for his role increased two years later when he starred in Almodóvar's controversial ''[[Tie Me Up! Tie Me Down!]]'' as a [[mental patient]] who kidnaps a porn star ([[Victoria Abril]]) and keeps her tied up until she returns his love. It was his breakthrough role in ''Tie Me Up! Tie Me Down!'', that helped spur him on to [[Hollywood]]. Almodóvar is credited for helping launch Banderas's international career, as he became a regular feature in his movies throughout the 1980s. === Breakthrough, 1991–1994 === In 1991, [[Madonna (entertainer)|Madonna]] introduced Banderas to [[Hollywood]]. The following year, still speaking minimal [[English language|English]], he began acting in U.S. films. Despite having to learn all his lines [[phonetically]], Banderas still managed to turn in a critically praised performance as a struggling musician in his first American drama film, ''[[The Mambo Kings]]'' (1992).{{Citation | url=http://www.rogerebert.com/reviews/the-mambo-kings-1992 | title=The Mambo Kings Review by Roger Ebert }} Banderas then broke through to mainstream American audiences in the film ''[[Philadelphia (movie)|Philadelphia]]'' (1993), as the lover of lawyer Andrew Beckett ([[Tom Hanks]]), who has AIDS. The film's success earned Banderas wide recognition, and the following year he was given a role in [[Neil Jordan]]'s high-profile [[Interview with the Vampire (film)|adaptation]] of [[Anne Rice]]'s ''[[Interview with the Vampire]]'', sharing the screen with [[Brad Pitt]]. === Worldwide recognition, 1995–present === He appeared in several major Hollywood releases in [[1995 in film|1995]], including a starring role in the [[Robert Rodriguez]]-directed film ''[[Desperado (film)|Desperado]]'' and the antagonist on the action film ''[[Assassins (film)|Assassins]]'', co-starred with [[Sylvester Stallone]]. In 1996, he starred alongside [[Madonna (entertainer)|Madonna]] in ''[[Evita (1996 film)|Evita]]'', an adaptation of the musical by [[Andrew Lloyd Webber]] and [[Tim Rice]] in which he played the narrator, Che, a role played by [[David Essex]] in the original 1978 West End production. He also made success with his role as the legendary masked swordsman [[Zorro]] in the 1998 film ''[[The Mask of Zorro]]''. In 1999 he starred in ''[[The 13th Warrior]]'', a movie about a [[Muslim]] caught up in a war between the [[Norsemen|Northman]] and human eating beasts. In 2001, he collaborated with [[Robert Rodriguez]] who cast him in the ''[[Spy Kids trilogy|Spy Kids]]'' film trilogy. He also starred in [[Michael Cristofer]]'s ''[[Original Sin (2001 film)|Original Sin]]'' alongside [[Angelina Jolie]] the same year. In 2002, he starred in [[Brian De Palma]]'s ''[[Femme Fatale (2002 film)|Femme Fatale]]'' opposite [[Rebecca Romijn]] and in [[Julie Taymor]]'s ''[[Frida]]'' with [[Salma Hayek]]. In 2003, he starred in the last installment of the trilogy ''[[Once Upon a Time in Mexico]]'' (in which he appeared with [[Johnny Depp]] and Hayek). Banderas' debut as a director was the poorly received ''[[Crazy in Alabama]]'' ([[1999 in film|1999]]), starring his then wife [[Melanie Griffith]].{{cite web|url=http://marriage.about.com/od/entertainmen1/p/melaniegriffith.htm|title=The History of Prenuptial Agreements|publisher=}} [[File:Antonio Banderas June07.jpg|250px|thumb|left|Banderas in June 2007]] In 2003, he returned to the musical genre, appearing to great acclaim in the Broadway revival of [[Maury Yeston]]'s musical ''[[Nine (musical)|Nine]]'', based on the film ''[[8½]]'', playing the prime role originated by [[Raúl Juliá]]. Banderas won both the Outer Critics Circle and Drama Desk awards, and was nominated for the [[Tony Award]] for best actor in a musical.{{cite web|title=United Press International|work=Banderas set for Broadway return|url=http://www.upi.com/NewsTrack/view.php?StoryID=20060404-034720-1455r|accessdate=6 April 2006|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060506115932/http://www.upi.com/NewsTrack/view.php?StoryID=20060404-034720-1455r |archivedate=6 May 2006|deadurl=no}} His performance is preserved on the Broadway cast recording released by [[PS Classics]]. Later that year, he received the [[Rita Moreno]] HOLA Award for Excellence from the [[Hispanic Organization of Latin Actors]] (HOLA).{{cite web|url=http://www.hellohola.org/photo_awards_2003.php|title=HOLA Awards 2003|publisher=Hispanic Organization of Latin Actors|accessdate=15 June 2016}} Banderas' voice role as [[Puss in Boots (Shrek)|Puss in Boots]] in ''[[Shrek 2]]'', ''[[Shrek the Third]]'', and the last film in the Shrek franchise, ''[[Shrek Forever After]]'', helped make the [[Character (arts)|character]] popular on the family film circuit. In 2005, he reprised his role as [[Zorro]] in ''[[The Legend of Zorro]]'', though this was not as successful as ''The Mask of Zorro''. In 2006, he starred in ''[[Take the Lead]]'', a high-set movie in which he played a [[ballroom dancing]] teacher. That year, he directed his second film ''[[Summer Rain (2006 film)|El camino de los ingleses]]'', and also received the L.A. Latino International Film Festival's "Gabi" Lifetime Achievement Award on 14 October.{{cite news|url=http://www.variety.com/vstory/VR1117952390.html?categoryid=38&cs=1|work=Variety|title=Banderas flies flag at LALIFF|date=22 October 2006}} He received a star on the Hollywood Walk of Fame on 6801 Hollywood Blvd. in 2005. [[File:Audiencia a actores de "Los 33" (19638685423).jpg|thumb|250px|Banderas pictured with the cast of ''[[The 33 (film)|The 33]]'', on 1 August 2015]] In 2011, the horror thriller ''[[The Skin I Live In]]'' marked the return of Banderas to [[Pedro Almodóvar]], the Spanish director who launched his international career. The two had not worked together since 1990 (''[[Tie Me Up! Tie Me Down!]]''). In ''The Skin I Live In'' he breaks out of the "[[Latin lover (stereotype)|Latin Lover]]" mold from his Hollywood work and stars as a calculating revenge-seeking plastic surgeon following the rape of his daughter. According to the [[Associated Press]] Banderas' performance is among his strongest in recent memory.{{cite web|url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/ap/article/ALeqM5jJinOIb9WP4KNqqGcTaWTFnhYG8w?docId=7f441b478ffa4a558992fe52e158b8f0|title=Spain's Almodovar eyes English-language project|last=Barchfield|first=Jenny|date=21 May 2011|publisher=[[Associated Press]]|accessdate=8 June 2011}} He again lent his voice to Puss in Boots, this time as the [[protagonist]] of the ''Shrek'' [[Spin-off (media)|spin-off]] [[prequel]], ''[[Puss in Boots (2011 film)|Puss in Boots]]''. This film reunited Banderas with [[Salma Hayek]] for the sixth time.{{cite web|url=http://extratv.warnerbros.com/2011/05/extra_raw_salma_hayek_and_anto.php|title=Extra' Raw: Salma Hayek and Antonio Banderas in Cannes|date=12 May 2011|publisher=[[Extra (U.S. TV program)|Extra]]}} == Business activities == He has invested some of his film earnings in [[Andalusia]]n products, which he promotes in Spain and the US. He owns 50% of a winery in [[Villalba de Duero]], Burgos, Spain, called '''Anta Banderas''', which produces red and rosé wines.[https://news.yahoo.com/s/ap/20090317/ap_en_ce/eu_spain_people_banderas;_ylt=AqgABzUfMqnAUXIq_1gRqctxFb8C Antonio Banderas Buys Winery]{{dead link|date=October 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} Yahoo News, 17 March 2009. He performed a voice-over for a [[computer-animated]] bee which can be seen in the United States in television commercials for [[Nasonex]],{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2005/10/27/AR2005102700603.html|title=Antonio Banderas Dons The Mask Once More|accessdate=5 December 2007|date =28 October 2005|first=Michael|last=O'Sullivan|publisher=Washington Post}} an allergy medication, and was seen in the 2007 Christmas advertising campaign for [[Marks & Spencer]], a British retailer.{{cite web|url=http://www.dailyrecord.co.uk/news/business-news/2007/11/06/marks-and-spencer-warn-of-poor-outlook-86908-20068181/|title=Marks And Spencer Warn of Poor Outlook|accessdate=5 December 2007|publisher=[[Daily Record (Scotland)|Daily Record]]| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071112150139/http://www.dailyrecord.co.uk/news/business-news/2007/11/06/marks-and-spencer-warn-of-poor-outlook-86908-20068181 |archivedate=12 November 2007|deadurl=no}} He is a veteran of the perfume industry. The actor has been working with fragrance and beauty multinational company [[Puig (company)|Puig]] for over ten years becoming one of the brand's most successful representatives. Banderas and Puig have successfully promoted a number of fragrances so far – ''Diavolo'', ''Diavolo for Women'', ''Mediterraneo'', ''Spirit'', and ''Spirit for Women''. After the success of ''Antonio for Men'' and ''Blue Seduction for Men'' in 2007, launched his latest ''Blue Seduction for Women'' the following year.[http://news.softpedia.com/news/Antonio-Banderas-Launches-Blue-Seduction-For-Women-88138.shtml Antonio Banderas Launches "Blue Seduction" for Women], Softpedia.com; accessed 17 September 2014. == Personal life == [[File:Antonio Banderas-Melanie Griffith-2010.jpg|thumb|220px|Banderas with [[Melanie Griffith]] at the ''[[Shrek Forever After]]'' premiere in May 2010.]] Banderas married Ana Leza in 1986 or 1988 (sources differ) and divorced in 1996. Banderas met and began a relationship with actress [[Melanie Griffith]] in 1995 while shooting ''[[Two Much]]''.{{cite web|url=http://us.hellomagazine.com/celebrities/gallery/201105205403/love-story-antonio-melanie/4/|title=Melanie and Antonio: How the 'Working Girl' fell for Spain's sexiest import|date=20 May 2011|publisher=(Slide 4 of 14) ''[[Hello (magazine)|Hello]]''|accessdate=9 June 2011| archivedate= 26 March 2017| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20170326192727/http://us.hellomagazine.com/celebrities/gallery/201105205403/love-story-antonio-melanie/4/| deadurl=no}}{{cite web| url = http://abcnews.go.com/Primetime/story?id=132090&page=1 |publisher=[[ABC News]]|title=Banderas: I'm No Latin Lover| date= 1 August 2003}} They married on 14 May 1996 in [[London]].''Hello'' (20 May 2011) [http://us.hellomagazine.com/celebrities/gallery/201105205403/love-story-antonio-melanie/5/ (slide 5 of 14)]. [https://web.archive.org/web/20170326193658/http://us.hellomagazine.com/celebrities/gallery/201105205403/love-story-antonio-melanie/5/ Archived] from the original on 26 March 2017. They have a daughter, Stella del Carmen Bandera (born 24 September 1996),''Hello'' (20 May 2011) [http://us.hellomagazine.com/celebrities/gallery/201105205403/love-story-antonio-melanie/6/ (slide 6 of 14)]. [https://web.archive.org/web/20170326194005/http://us.hellomagazine.com/celebrities/gallery/201105205403/love-story-antonio-melanie/6/ Archived] from the original on 26 March 2017. who appeared onscreen with Griffith in Banderas' directorial debut, ''[[Crazy in Alabama]]'' (1999).''Hello'' (20 May 2011) [http://us.hellomagazine.com/celebrities/gallery/201105205403/love-story-antonio-melanie/7/ (side 7 of 14)]. [https://web.archive.org/web/20170326194314/http://us.hellomagazine.com/celebrities/gallery/201105205403/love-story-antonio-melanie/7/ Archived] from the original on 26 March 2017. In 2002, the couple received the Stella Adler Angel Award for their extensive [[philanthropy]].''Hello'' (20 May 2011) [http://us.hellomagazine.com/celebrities/gallery/201105205403/love-story-antonio-melanie/9/ (slide 9 of 14)]. [https://web.archive.org/web/20170326194635/http://us.hellomagazine.com/celebrities/gallery/201105205403/love-story-antonio-melanie/9/ Archived] from the original on 26 March 2017. Griffith has a tattoo of Banderas' name on her right arm.''Hello'' (20 May 2011) [http://us.hellomagazine.com/celebrities/gallery/201105205403/love-story-antonio-melanie/8/ (slide 8 of 14)]. [https://web.archive.org/web/20170326194556/http://us.hellomagazine.com/celebrities/gallery/201105205403/love-story-antonio-melanie/8/ Archived] from the original on 26 March 2017. In June 2014, Griffith and Banderas released a statement announcing their intention to divorce "in a loving and friendly manner".{{Cite news|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2014-06-07/griffith-banderas-announce-loving-and-friendly-divorce/5507558|title=Melanie Griffith and Antonio Banderas announce divorce|date=2014-06-07|work=ABC News|access-date=2017-12-10|language=en-AU}} According to the petition filed in the Los Angeles Superior Court, the couple had "irreconcilable differences" that led to their separation.{{Cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-people-melaniegriffith-antoniobandera/melanie-griffith-files-for-divorce-from-antonio-banderas-idUSKBN0EH27T20140606|title=Melanie Griffith files for divorce from Antonio Banderas|date=6 Jun 2014|work=Reuters|accessdate=2017-12-10}} The divorce became official in December 2015.{{Cite news|url=http://www.usmagazine.com/celebrity-news/news/melanie-griffith-antonio-banderas-finalize-divorce-whos-getting-what-w159235|title=Melanie Griffith, Antonio Banderas Finalize Divorce: Who's Getting What?|date=2015-12-08|work=Us Weekly|access-date=2017-12-10|language=en-US}} In 1996, Banderas appeared among other figures of Spanish culture in a video supporting the [[Spanish Socialist Workers' Party]] lists in the [[Spanish general election, 1996|general election]]. A longtime supporter of [[Málaga CF]],{{Cite web |url= http://www.cigaraficionado.com/Cigar/CA_Profiles/People_Profile/0,2540,221,00.html |title= Cigar Aficionado {{!}} People Profile {{!}} Antonio Banderas |access-date= 13 August 2012 |archive-url= https://www.webcitation.org/69yiuZO3Q?url=http://www.cigaraficionado.com/webfeatures/show/id/Behind-the-Mask_6197 |archive-date= 17 August 2012 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }} he is also an officer (mayordomo de trono) of a Roman Catholic religious brotherhood in [[Málaga]] and travels during [[Holy Week]] to take part [[Holy Week in Málaga|in the processions]],''[http://www.abc.es/20100329/gente-famosos/antonio-banderas-semana-santa-201003291143.html Antonio Banderas, en la Semana Santa malagueña]'', ''ABC'', 30 March 2010. although in an interview with ''People'' magazine, Banderas had once described himself as an [[Agnosticism|agnostic]].{{cite web|title=Antonio Banderas Puts on His Dancing Shoes|url=http://www.people.com/people/article/0,,1181281,00.html|work=People|accessdate=28 June 2011}} In 2009, Banderas went under surgery for a benign tumor in his back.{{cite web|title=Antonio Banderas: ho avuto un tumore alla schiena|url=https://www.ok-salute.it/benessere/antonio-banderas-ho-avuto-un-tumore-alla-schiena|date=24 February 2014|accessdate=5 September 2017}} In May 2010, Banderas received an [[honorary doctorate]] from the [[University of Málaga]] in the city where he was born.{{cite web|url=http://www.hellomagazine.com/celebrities/201005063447/antonio-banderas/honorary-doctorate/almodovar/1|title=Antonio Banderas receives {{Sic|nolink=y|honou|rary|expected=honorary}} doctorate as news breaks of 'brutal' new role|date=6 May 2010|publisher=[[Hello (magazine)|Hello]]|accessdate=9 June 2011}} Banderas received an honorary degree from [[Dickinson College]] in 2000. Banderas has always struggled with the pronunciation of certain [[English language|English]] words, as he mentioned in a 2011 article with [[GQ]] Magazine. "The word that really gets me is animals, I just can never say it properly, whenever it is in a film I have to get it changed for a synonym." "In Zorro, I had a line changed from 'You look like a bunch of animals' to 'you look like a collection of beasts' it worked much better, so I don't care". In 2013, he called on Europe and the United States to emulate [[Hugo Chávez]] in Venezuela and nationalize big corporations as a solution to the [[Great Recession|global economic crisis]].{{cite web|url=http://www.thelocal.es/20131120/chvez-ideas-wil-solve-crisis-antonio-banderas|title='Chávez ideas will solve crisis': Antonio Banderas|date=20 November 2013|work=The Local}} In June 2015, web|url=http://www.israelnationalnews.com/News/News.aspx/203022|title=Hollywood celebs raise $31 million for IDF soldiers|website=Israel National News}} In August 2015, Banderas enrolled in a {{Use dmy dates|date=June 2013}} {{Unreferenced|date=December 2009}} {{Infobox television | show_name = Asia Market Wrap | image = CNBC Asia - Asia Market Wrap logo.jpg | caption = | camera = | picture_format = | audio_format = | runtime = 120 [[minute]]s (2 [[hour]]s) | creator = | developer = | producer = | executive_producer = | presenter = [[Christine Tan]] (2004-2005)
[[Martin Soong]] (1998-2003) | voices = | narrated = | theme_music_composer = | opentheme = | endtheme = | country = | location = | language = English | network = [[CNBC Asia]] | first_aired = 1998-02-02 | last_aired = 2005-12-02 | num_series = | num_episodes = | list_episodes = | preceded_by = | followed_by = '''''[[Worldwide Exchange]]''''' | related = | website = }} '''''Asia Market Wrap''''' is a [[business]] [[news]] programme aired on [[CNBC Asia]] between 1600-1800 ([[Hong Kong]]/[[Singapore]]/[[Taiwan]] time, until December 2005. The show also aired on [[CNBC US]] on 5:30 to 6AM ET until 2000, then it was moved to [[CNBC World]]. Anchored by [[Christine Tan]], ''Asia Market Wrap'' examined the day's headlines and numbers, with in-depth analysis of the day's financial news, interviewing key money managers, market experts and corporate chiefs. The programme, comes from its original edition on CNBC US, '''''[[Market Wrap]]''''', included several segments, such as ''Australia Market Wrap'', ''China Business Briefing'' and ''Eye on India''. '''''[[Asia Market Week]]''''' - a weekly wrap-up of the market action in Asia - aired between 17:30-18:00 on Fridays. Prior to [[Martin Soong]]'s original departure from CNBC Asia, he was the programme's regular presenter (the programme was billed as ''Asia Market Wrap with Martin Soong''). When he returned to present '''''[[Asia Squawk Box]]''''', Tan was moved to present ''Asia Market Wrap'' instead. The programme was not aired on CNBC Asia's [[CNBC Australia]], local opt-out - it was replaced by [[CNBC Europe|CNBC Europe's]] ''[[Morning Exchange (CNBC Europe)|Morning Exchange]]'' (1600 - 1700 HK/SG Time) and [[CNBC|CNBC's]] '''''[[Wake Up Call (CNBC)|Wake Up Call]]''''' (1700 - 1800 HK/SG/TWN Time). The programme ended on 2 December 2005 and was replaced by '''''[[Worldwide Exchange]]''''' on 19 December 2005. Tan continues as the Asian presenter of this programme, joined by CNBC's [[Michelle Caruso-Cabrera]] (used for 2005-07-10-19 to due General assignment), now anchored by [[Brian Shactman]] (2007-10-22-present) and CNBC Europe's [[Ross Westgate]]. ==''Asia Market Wrap'' anchors== *[[Bill Hartley (journalist)|Bill Hartley]] and [[Lorraine Hahn]] (1996(?)-1998) *[[Martin Soong]] (1998–2003) *[[Christine Tan]] (2004–2005) {{CNBC Asia Business Day}} [[Category:CNBC Asia programs]] [[Category:CNBC programs]] [[Category:Television news programmes]] [[Category:Hong Kong television news programmes]] [[Category:Singaporean television news programmes]] [[Category:Taiwanese television news programmes]] [[Category:1990s Hong Kong television series]] [[Category:1990s Singaporean television series]] [[Category:1990s Taiwanese television series]] [[Category:2000s Hong Kong television series]] [[Category:2000s Singaporean television series]] [[Category:2000s Taiwanese television series]] [[Category:1998 Hong Kong television series debuts]] [[Category:2005 Hong Kong television series endings]] [[Category:1998 Singaporean television series debuts]] [[Category:2005 Singaporean television series endings]] [[Category:1998 Taiwanese television series debuts]] [[Category:2005 Taiwanese television series endings]] [[Category:Business-related television series]] {{News-tv-prog-stub}}

{{Infobox company | name = BOARD International S.A. | logo = [[Image:BOARD International Logo.png|frameless|Logo]] | type = [[Private company|Private]] | foundation = 1994 | location = [[Chiasso]], [[Switzerland]] | industry = [[Business Intelligence]], [[Corporate Performance Management]], [[Software]] | products = BOARD 10 | homepage = [http://www.board.com/ www.board.com] }}
'''BOARD International S.A.''' is a [[Business Intelligence]] (BI) and [[Corporate Performance Management]] (CPM) [[software]] vendor known for its [[BOARD International#Products|BOARD toolkit]]. The company is headquartered in [[Chiasso]], [[Switzerland]], where it was founded in 1994, and Boston (MA).<ref name="Nucleus">{{cite web|title='Research Note: Benefits of BOARD International'|url=http://nucleusresearch.com/research/notes-and-reports/benefits-of-board-international/|publisher=Nucleus Research|format=PDF|accessdate=Oct 19, 2012}}</ref> While its core markets are still located in Europe, BOARD International has been expanding globally and now operates in 15 countries worldwide.<ref name="MQBI">{{cite web |url=http://www.gartner.com/technology/reprints.do?id=1-196WFCB&ct=120207&st=sb |title=Magic Quadrant for Business Intelligence Platforms |first=John |last=Hagerty |last2=Sallam |first2=Rita L. |last3=Richardson |first3=James |publisher=Gartner |date=Feb 6, 2012 |accessdate=Oct 19, 2012}}</ref><ref name="Loc">{{cite web|title='World Wide Locations' |url=http://www.board.com/in/company-6/board-international/world-wide-locations |publisher=BOARD International |accessdate=Apr 15, 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140416175239/http://www.board.com/in/company-6/board-international/world-wide-locations |archivedate=2014-04-16 |df= }}</ref> It has a total of over 2,500 customers from a number of different industries,<ref name="Nucleus"/> including large international corporations such as [[ABB Group|ABB]], [[Best Western]], [[GlaxoSmithKline]], [[NEC]], and [[Puma SE|Puma]].<ref>{{cite web|title='BOARD - Reference' |url=http://www.board.com/business-intelligence-software/clients |publisher=BOARD International |accessdate=Oct 19, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121027040512/http://www.board.com/business-intelligence-software/clients |archivedate=2012-10-27 |df= }}</ref>
== Products ==
BOARD International offers only one product, the '''BOARD toolkit'''.<ref>{{cite web|title='BOARD - All In One' |url=http://www.board.com/business-intelligence-software/allinone |publisher=BOARD International |accessdate=Oct 19, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121006073642/http://www.board.com/business-intelligence-software/allinone |archivedate=2012-10-06 |df= }}</ref> It combines various [[Business Intelligence|BI]] and [[Corporate Performance Management|CPM]] functionalities within a single graphical software environment.<ref name="MQBI"/> BOARD's BI capabilities include multi-dimensional analysis, ''ad hoc'' querying, dashboarding and reporting, while its CPM capabilities include budgeting, planning and forecasting as well as "other finance-related activities".<ref>{{cite web|title='Gleansight - Agile Business Intelligence - Q4 2012'|first=Jeff |last=Zabin |authorlink=Jeff Zabin|last2=O'Brien |first2=Tim |last3=Forgash |first3=Amanda|url=http://www.gleanster.com/reports/reports/agile-business-intelligence#.UIZUOMUxoWb|publisher=Gleanster|format=PDF|accessdate=Oct 23, 2012}}</ref> Like [[Business Intelligence software]] in general, BOARD is used in an effort to improve productivity and decision making while lowering costs.<ref name="Nucleus"/> It does not require any [[Computer programming|programming]] skills to build BI and CPM applications.<ref name="MQBI"/>
=== Technology ===
As of version 7, the BOARD toolkit features a [[service-oriented architecture]] that relies heavily on [[Microsoft]] technology, especially the [[.NET Framework]] with its [[Windows Communication Foundation]]. This allows for a tight integration with other Microsoft products, such as [[Microsoft Office]], but requires [[Microsoft Windows|Windows]] in order to run the full client, a limitation which has been identified by [[Gartner]] as a possible factor for preventing a deeper market penetration.<ref name="MQBI"/><ref name="Architecture">{{cite web|title='BOARD - Architecture' |url=http://www.board.com/business-intelligence-software/architecture/IN-Overview |publisher=BOARD International |accessdate=Oct 22, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120904131507/http://www.board.com/business-intelligence-software/architecture/IN-Overview |archivedate=2012-09-04 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title='BOARD - Architecture: Office Integration' |url=http://www.board.com/business-intelligence-software/architecture/IN-officeintegration |publisher=BOARD International |accessdate=Oct 22, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121213093835/http://www.board.com/business-intelligence-software/architecture/IN-officeintegration |archivedate=2012-12-13 |df= }}</ref><ref name="MQCPM">{{cite web |url=http://www.boardargentina.com/board-blog/archives/GartnerMagicQuadrant2012forCorporatePerformanceManagementSuites.pdf |title=Magic Quadrant for Corporate Performance Management Suites |format=PDF |first=John E. |last=Van Decker |last2=Chandler |first2=Neil |last3=Iervolino |first3=Christopher |publisher=Gartner |date=Mar 19, 2012 |accessdate=Oct 22, 2012 }}{{Dead link|date=November 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title='BOARD International Releases BOARD 7 - BeyeNetwork'|url=http://www.b-eye-network.com/view/10258|accessdate=Oct 22, 2012}}</ref>
In 2012, the company introduced an update of its proprietary [[multidimensional database]] that BOARD is based on. This new technology was labelled as ''HBMP (Hybrid Bitwise Memory Pattern)''. It introduced a new compression method and combines disk-based and [[In-memory database|in-memory]] database approaches. It supports both [[Relational database|relational]] and [[Multidimensional database|multidimensional]] data models.<ref>{{cite web|title='BOARD - Toolkit' |url=http://www.board.com/business-intelligence/HBMP |publisher=BOARD International |accessdate=Oct 22, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120910183312/http://www.board.com/business-intelligence/HBMP |archivedate=2012-09-10 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title='HBMP: The New Frontier of In-Memory Business Intelligence and CPM -- TDWI -The Data Warehousing Institute'|url=http://tdwi.org/whitepapers/2012/04/hbmp-the-new-frontier-of-in-memory-business-intelligence-and-cpm.aspx|publisher=TDWI|accessdate=Oct 22, 2012}}</ref>
=== Usage ===
According to ''The BI Survey 12'', a worldwide [[Business Intelligence|BI]] and [[Corporate Performance Management|CPM]] user survey, the most widely used application areas of BOARD are [[financial reporting|reporting]], ad-hoc querying, [[Dashboard (management information systems)|dashboarding]], budgeting & planning, [[OLAP]] analysis, visual analysis & data discovery, [[Predictive analytics|predictive analysis]] & [[data mining]] and [[Consolidation (business)|financial consolidation]] (in descending order of use frequency).<ref name="BIS12">{{cite web|url=http://www.board.com/business-intelligence/RegDownload?OpenForm&id=149FEC616C3E6E09C1257A94003FB76C&img=BOARD_in_TheBISurvey12_Thumb.jpg |title=The BI Survey 12: BOARD in The BI Survey 12 |format=PDF |publisher=BARC |accessdate=Oct 26, 2012 }}{{dead link|date=October 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
=== Effectiveness ===
A 2012 case study by [[Nucleus Research]] analyzed the effectiveness of BOARD when used as a company-wide [[business analytics]] solution. The research was based on three years' worth of actual data from Marketing General, a BOARD customer. It came to the conclusion that the introduction of BOARD allowed Marketing General to "raise profits, reduce customer churn and increase organizational productivity" while producing an average annual benefit of $119,962. It was calculated that, on average, the system saved 6 working hours a week per manager and IT worker.<ref name="ROI">{{cite web |url=http://nucleusresearch.com/research/roi-case-studies/roi-case-study-board-marketing-general/|title=ROI Case Study: Board |format=PDF |publisher=Nucleus Research |date=Oct 2012 |accessdate=Oct 26, 2012}}</ref>
== Recognition ==
In recent years, BOARD has been frequently included in major publications on the [[Business Intelligence|BI]] and [[Corporate Performance Management|CPM]] markets.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.gartner.com/id=1578314|title=Magic Quadrant for Corporate Performance Management Suites |format=PDF |first2=John E. |last2=Van Decker |last=Chandler |first=Neil |publisher=Gartner |date=Mar 8, 2011 |accessdate=Oct 23, 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.gartner.com/id=1531017|title=Magic Quadrant for Business Intelligence Platforms |format=PDF |first3=John |last3=Hagerty |last=Sallam |first=Rita L. |last2=Richardson |first2=James |last4=Hostmann |first4=Bill |publisher=Gartner |date=Jan 27, 2011 |accessdate=Oct 23, 2012}}</ref>
In late 2012, it was included in The BI Survey 12, "the world's largest and most detailed annual survey of [[business intelligence software]] usage".<ref>{{cite web|title='The BI Survey 12 - Products covered'|url=http://www.bi-survey.com/index.php?id=118|publisher=BARC|accessdate=Oct 22, 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title='The BI Survey 12 - A product overview'|url=http://www.bi-survey.com/index.php?id=35|publisher=BARC|accessdate=Oct 22, 2012}}</ref> BOARD also was featured in two of [[Gartner]]'s 2012 [[Gartner Magic Quadrant|Magic Quadrants]]: the ''Magic Quadrant for [[Business Intelligence]] Platforms''<ref name="MQBI"/> and the ''Magic Quadrant for [[Corporate Performance Management]] Suites''.<ref name="MQCPM"/> BOARD International was the only single-product vendor to be included in both quadrants that year.<ref name="MQBI"/><ref name="MQCPM"/>
In terms of technology, the introduction of the [[.NET Framework|.NET]]-based BOARD 7 earned the company a ''Microsoft. NET Swiss Innovation Award'' in 2010.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.microsoft.com/switzerland/msdn/de/awards/tech_Gewinner10_de.aspx|title=Microsoft Switzerland Awards|publisher=Microsoft|accessdate=Oct 22, 2012}}</ref>
== Offices ==
Apart from its [[Switzerland|Swiss]] headquarters, BOARD International has a total of 17 offices spread across five continents and 15 countries.<ref name="Loc" /> The company has recently been expanding, opening three new offices in 2011 (China, Japan and Mexico), but still has a higher presence in Europe than it does elsewhere.<ref name="MQBI"/>
BOARD International's worldwide subsidiaries and their exact locations are as follows:
* BOARD Argentina ([[Buenos Aires]], [[Argentina]]) * BOARD Asia Pacific ([[Singapore]]) * BOARD Australia ([[Sydney]], [[Australia]])<ref name="Loc" /> * BOARD Belgium & Luxemburg ([[Brussels]], [[Belgium]]) * BOARD Deutschland ([[Bad Homburg]] and [[Munich]], [[Germany]]) * BOARD France ([[Paris]]) <ref>{{cite web|title='BOARD International opens a new office in France to support international growth |url=http://www.board.com/in/company-6/board-international/news/709-board-international-opens-a-new-office-in-france-to-support-international-growth |publisher=BOARD International |accessdate=June 26, 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150626130242/http://www.board.com/in/company-6/board-international/news/709-board-international-opens-a-new-office-in-france-to-support-international-growth |archivedate=June 26, 2015 |df= }}</ref> * BOARD Hong Kong ([[Hong Kong]], [[China]]) * BOARD India ([[Mumbai]], [[India]]) * BOARD Italia ([[Milan]], [[Italy]]) * BOARD Iberica, S.L. ([[Barcelona]] and [[Madrid]], [[Spain]]) * BOARD Mexico ([[Mexico City]], [[Mexico]]) * BOARD Middle East ([[Dubai]], [[United Arab Emirates]]) * BOARD Netherlands ([[Amsterdam]], [[The Netherlands]]) * BOARD Nordics ([[Kopenhagen]], [[Denmark]]) * BOARD Software K.K. ([[Yokohama]], [[Japan]]) * BOARD UK ([[London]],<ref>{{cite web|title='BOARD International - Google+ - The view from our new office is pretty amazing...'|url=https://plus.google.com/102158394978796506125/posts/7Cn32yDxHfD|publisher=BOARD International|accessdate=Apr 15, 2014}}</ref> [[UK]]) * BOARD USA ([[Boston]] and [[Austin]], [[United States]])

'''''Boxing on NBC''''' is the de facto title for [[NBC Sports]]' [[boxing]] television coverage.<ref>[http://www.google.com/search?hl=en&tbs=tl%3A1%2Ctl_num%3A100&q=Boxing+on+NBC&cts=1278143635556&aq=f&aqi=&aql=&oq=&gs_rfai= Google Search – ''Boxing on NBC'']</ref>
==History==
===''Gillette Cavalcade of Sports''=== The earliest incarnation of NBC's boxing telecasts could be traced back to 1944. Although technically, an anthology program, the ''[[Gillette Cavalcade of Sports|Cavalcade of Sports]]'' was best known for Friday night boxing (from [[Madison Square Garden]]) on NBC from 1944 through 1960, and (after NBC decided against featuring boxing due to sensitivity over criminal allegations in the sport) then for several more years on [[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]]. When ''Cavalcade of Sports'' closed up shop on June 24, 1960 after a 14-year period, it marked the longest continuous run of any boxing program in television history.
====''Boxing from St. Nicholas Arena''==== Another boxing program called ''[[Boxing from St. Nicholas Arena]]'' aired on NBC during the same period (more specifically, from 1946–1948) as the ''Cavalcade of Sports''.
===''Sportsworld'' and partnership with Telemundo=== In 2003, NBC entered a [[joint venture]] with [[Telemundo]] and boxing promotional group Main Events.<ref>[http://www.eastsideboxing.com/boxing-news/everlast2304.php Everlast Will Sponsor NBC, Telemundo And Main Events Pro Boxing Television Series] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110325115026/http://www.eastsideboxing.com/boxing-news/everlast2304.php |date=March 25, 2011 }}</ref> On three consecutive Saturday afternoons – May 3, 10 and 17 – NBC Sports and Telemundo provided live coverage from the same Main Events-promoted boxing event. It marked the first time that NBC broadcast professional boxing since 1992, when ''[[Sportsworld (U.S. TV series)|Sportsworld]]''<ref>[https://www.nytimes.com/1982/11/07/sports/sports-people-boxer-skips-bout.html?scp=1&sq=NBC+SportsWorld&st=nyt SPORTS PEOPLE; Boxer Skips Bout – November 7, 1982]</ref><ref>[https://www.nytimes.com/1982/07/13/sports/boxing-a-weapon-in-tv-rating-game.html?scp=2&sq=NBC+SportsWorld&st=nyt Boxing a Weapon In TV Rating Game – July 13, 1982]</ref><ref>[https://www.nytimes.com/1988/03/09/sports/tv-sports-nbc-plans-to-take-tougher-approach.html?scp=1&sq=NBC+SportsWorld&st=nyt TV SPORTS; NBC Plans to Take Tougher Approach – March 9, 1988]</ref> ended its run after 14 years.
The following year, NBC and Telemundo renewed their partnership with a series of five Saturday cards beginning April 17.<ref>[http://nbcsports.msnbc.com/id/4354886 Boxing returns to NBC with 5-fight series]</ref>
===NBCSN's ''Fight Night''=== Beginning in 2006, when the [[NBCSN]] was known as Versus, they began airing matches from [[Bob Arum]]'s [[Top Rank]] group. [[Nick Charles (sportscaster)|Nick Charles]] was one of the announcers. In 2010, Versus broadcast the [[World Series of Boxing]].
NBCSN's ''Fight Night'' series premiered on January 21, 2012 from [[2300 Arena]] in Philadelphia with [[Kenny Rice]] and trainer [[Freddie Roach (boxing)|Freddie Roach]] on the call and [[Chris Mannix]] of ''[[Sports Illustrated]]'' serving as reporter and researcher.
===Premier Boxing Champions=== {{Main|Premier Boxing Champions}} In January 2015, NBC announced that [[Al Michaels]] would host ringside along with blow-by-blow man [[Marv Albert]]<ref>{{cite web |url=http://awfulannouncing.com/2015/marv-albert-sugar-ray-leonard-nbcs-boxing-announcing-team.html |title=Marv Albert and Sugar Ray Leonard are NBC’s boxing announcing team|last1=Yoder|first=Matt|last2= |first2= |date=9 February 2015|website=Awful Announcing|publisher= |accessdate=}}</ref> and color commentator [[Sugar Ray Leonard]] for the ''PBC on NBC''<ref>{{cite web |url=http://awfulannouncing.com/2015/nbc-bringing-matrix-boxing-well-sort.html|title=NBC is bringing The Matrix to boxing … well, sort of|last1=Fang|first1=Ken|last2= |first2= |date=15 February 2015|website=Awful Announcing |publisher= |access-date=}}</ref> Saturday night bouts. In partnership with [[Al Haymon|Haymon Boxing]],<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.nydailynews.com/sports/more-sports/al-haymon-mia-nbc-announces-new-prime-time-boxing-plan-article-1.2078099|title=Al Haymon MIA as NBC announces new prime time boxing schedule |last1=Abramson|first=Mitch|last2= |first2= |date=14 January 2015|website=New York Daily News|publisher= |accessdate=}}</ref> NBC would televise 20 ''PBC on NBC'' events<ref>{{cite web |url=https://nypost.com/2015/01/15/al-michaels-to-call-top-notch-boxing-on-nbc-who-will-watch/|title=Al Michaels to call top-notch boxing on NBC — who will watch?|last1=Willis|first1=George|last2= |first2= |date=15 January 2015|website=New York Post|publisher= |accessdate=}}</ref> (beginning on March 7<ref>{{cite web |url=http://awfulannouncing.com/2015/premier-boxing-champions-debut-nbc-primetime-mixed-bag-ratings.html|title=Premier Boxing Champions debut on NBC in primetime a mixed bag in ratings|last1=Yoder|first1=Matt |last2= |first2= |date=9 March 2015|website=Awful Announcing|publisher= |access-date=}}</ref>), including five to be shown in prime time on Saturday nights.
==Notable bouts on NBC== On July 2, 1921, NBC's future owner [[RCA]] and its [[Hoboken, New Jersey]] based radio station [[WJY (Hoboken, New Jersey)|WJY]] presented live coverage of the [[Jack Dempsey]] vs. [[Georges Carpentier]] heavyweight title fight. In the first major sporting event to be broadcast to a regional audience, ringside announcer J. Andrew White called Dempsey's fourth-round knockout victory.
On June 1, 1939, NBC (or technically, WNBT, which would eventually becoming NBC's [[Flagship (broadcasting)|flagship]] affiliate, [[WNBC]]) became the first American television network to broadcast a boxing match. Emanating from Yankee Stadium in New York City, Bill Stern provided the blow-by-blow commentary for the fight between [[Lou Nova]] and [[Max Baer (boxer)|Max Baer]].
On the premiere episode of ''[[Gillette_Cavalcade_of_Sports#As_Cavalcade_of_Sports|Cavalcade of Sports]]'' (airing on September 29, 1944), NBC broadcast a 15-round bout between [[Willie Pep]] and [[Chalky Wright]].
On June 19, 1946, at Yankee Stadium, [[Joe Louis]] defeated [[Billy Conn]] in the first [[television|televised]] World Heavyweight Championship bout ever. 146,000 people watched it on TV, also setting a record for the most seen world heavyweight bout in history. One year later on NBC on December 5, Joe Louis defeated [[Jersey Joe Walcott]] to retain the world heavyweight title.
On February 14, 1951, [[Sugar Ray Robinson]] defeated [[Jake LaMotta]] in 13 rounds for the world middleweight title.
On the March 26, 1954 edition of ''Gillette Cavalcade of Sports'' from New York City's [[Madison Square Garden (1925)|Madison Square Garden]], Al Andrews and [[Gustav Scholz]] fought in NBC's first [[Color television|color]] transmission of a sporting event.
On the July 14, 1979 edition of ''[[Sportsworld (U.S. TV series)|NBC SportsWorld]]'', NBC aired an eight round long exhibition match from [[Denver]]'s [[Mile High Stadium]] between former [[Denver Broncos|Broncos]] defensive lineman [[Lyle Alzado]] and [[Muhammad Ali]]. [[Sam Nover]]<ref>{{YouTube|title=Ali Boxing vs Football and Lyle Alzado МУХАММЕД АЛИ|id=iWBbVFUVulk}}</ref> provided the blow-by-blow commentary with [[Dick Schaap]] reporting. Two years later on June 25, ''NBC SportsWorld'' aired [[Sugar Ray Leonard]]'s victory in the ninth round against [[Ayub Kalule]]<ref>{{YouTube|title=Sugar Ray Leonard vs Ayub Kalule|id=bbas0GWb5io}}</ref> to become the [[World Boxing Association|WBA]] [[List_of_WBA_world_champions#Super_welterweight|World Light Middleweight champion]]. [[Marv Albert]] and [[Ferdie Pacheco]] called the action from [[Houston]]'s [[Astrodome]].
On May 20, 1985, NBC broadcast in [[prime time]] the [[International Boxing Federation|IBF]] [[List of heavyweight boxing champions|Heavyweight Championship of the World]] bout between [[Larry Holmes]] and [[Carl Williams (boxer)|Carl Williams]]. In what would become NBC's final prime time boxing broadcast for 30 years, [[Dick Enberg]]<ref>{{YouTube|title=Larry Holmes vs Carl "The Truth" Williams (NBC Broadcast)|id=M7qE_ZV4uRU}}</ref> hosted while Marv Albert provided blow-by-blow coverage with analyst Ferdie Pacheco.
==Commentators== *[[Marv Albert]]<ref>{{cite web |url=https://sports.yahoo.com/news/how-marv-albert--73--could-help-boxing-regain-traction-with-younger-crowd-060429525-boxing.html|title=How Marv Albert, 73, could help boxing regain traction with younger crowd|last1=Iole |first1=Kevin|last2= |first2= |date=1 March 2015|website=Yahoo Sports|publisher= |access-date=}}</ref> *[[Laila Ali]] *[[Teddy Atlas]] – Atlas worked as boxing commentator for [[Olympics on NBC|NBC]]'s coverage of the Olympic Games in Sydney ([[Boxing at the 2000 Summer Olympics|2000]]), Athens ([[Boxing at the 2004 Summer Olympics|2004]]) and Beijing ([[Boxing at the 2008 Summer Olympics|2008]]).<ref>[http://weblogs.baltimoresun.com/sports/mediumwell/blog/2008/07/your_nbc_olympics_lineup.html Medium Well: Your NBC Olympics lineup – A blog on sports media, news and networks – baltimoresun.com<!-- Bot generated title -->] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080803182204/http://weblogs.baltimoresun.com/sports/mediumwell/blog/2008/07/your_nbc_olympics_lineup.html |date=2008-08-03 }}</ref> *[[Al Bernstein]] – In 1992 and 1996, he served as the boxing analyst for [[Olympics on NBC|NBC]]'s coverage of the [[Summer Olympic Games]]. *[[Bob Costas]]<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.si.com/more-sports/2015/03/30/marv-alberts-al-michaels-bob-costas-katie-nolan-garbage-time|title=Marv Albert, Al Michaels, Bob Costas to join forces for a broadcast|last1=Deitsch|first1=Richard|last2= |first2= |date=30 March 2015|website=Sports Illustrated|publisher= |access-date=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://awfulannouncing.com/2015/marv-albert-bob-costas-and-al-michaels-to-work-together-for-the-first-time-ever.html|title=Marv Albert, Bob Costas and Al Michaels to work together for the first time ever|last1=Fang|first1=Ken|last2= |first2= |date=1 April 2015|website=Awful Announcing|publisher= |access-date=}}</ref> – On March 30, 2015, it was announced Costas would join forces with [[Marv Albert]] (blow-by-blow) and [[Al Michaels]] (host) on the April 11, 2015 edition of NBC's [[Prime time|primetime]] ''PBC on NBC'' boxing series. Costas was added to serve as a special contributor for the event from [[Barclays Center]] in [[Brooklyn]]. He would narrate and write a feature on the storied history of boxing in [[New York City]]. *[[Dick Enberg]] – In 1975, Enberg joined [[NBC Sports]]. For the next 25 years, he broadcast a plethora of sports and events for NBC, including the [[NFL on NBC|National Football League]], [[Major League Baseball on NBC|Major League Baseball]], the [[NBA on NBC|National Basketball Association]], the [[U.S. Open (golf)|U.S. Open]] [[Golf Channel on NBC|golf]] championship, [[College Football on NBC|college football]], [[College Basketball on NBC|college basketball]], the [[Wimbledon Championships|Wimbledon]] and [[French Open]] [[Tennis on NBC|tennis]] tournaments, heavyweight boxing, [[Breeders' Cup]] and other [[Thoroughbred Racing on NBC|horse racing events]], and the [[Olympics on NBC|Olympic Games]]. *[[Ray Forrest]] – Wearing a tuxedo to intone the formal sign-on when NBC went on the air each evening, Forrest announced every station break and every program. He covered [[wrestling]], [[boxing]], [[hockey]], [[horse racing]] and movie premieres. *[[Jim Gray (sportscaster)|Jim Gray]] – Gray served as a reporter for [[NBC Sports]] coverage of [[Boxing at the 2008 Summer Olympics]].<ref>[http://weblogs.baltimoresun.com/sports/mediumwell/blog/2008/07/your_nbc_olympics_lineup.html Medium Well: Your NBC Olympics lineup – A blog on sports media, news and networks – baltimoresun.com<!-- Bot generated title -->] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080803182204/http://weblogs.baltimoresun.com/sports/mediumwell/blog/2008/07/your_nbc_olympics_lineup.html |date=2008-08-03 }}</ref> *[[Sugar Ray Leonard]] – Leonard has worked as a boxing analyst for [[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]], [[CBS]], [[NBC]], [[ESPN]], [[HBO]] and [[Epix (TV channel)|EPIX]]. *[[Chris Mannix]] – With NBC Sports, Mannix serves as ringside reporter for ''[[Boxing_on_NBC#NBC_Sports_Network.27s_Fight_Night|Fight Night]]'' and a boxing insider for ''[[NBC SportsTalk]]''. * Wally Matthews<ref>[http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/vault/article/magazine/MAG1068122/2/index.htm BEST JOURNALISM—1) NBC's Olympic boxing coverage. Marv Albert, Ferdie Pacheco and Wally Matthews handled complex stories extraordinarily well.]</ref> *[[Al Michaels]]<ref>{{cite web |url=http://awfulannouncing.com/2015/nbc-brings-boxing-back-prime-time-hosted-al-michaels.html |title=NBC brings boxing back to prime time, hosted by Al Michaels |last1=Casselberry |first1=Ian |last2= |first2= |date=16 January 2015 |website=Awful Announcing |publisher= |accessdate=}}</ref> *[[Sam Nover]] – In 1980, Nover signed a contract with [[NBC Sports]] with the main intention of working as boxing commentator at the [[1980 Summer Olympics|Moscow Olympics]], but was denied the opportunity when the United States boycotted the games. He also worked many venues for ''[[Sportsworld (U.S. TV series)|NBC SportsWorld]]'', including boxing and was partnered for many years with former Lightweight Champion, [[Ray Mancini|Ray "Boom Boom" Mancini]] and [[Alexis Argüello]]. *[[Ferdie Pacheco]]<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.nbcsports.com/our-history#decade_6|title=Sugar Ray Leonard becomes World Champion|last= |first= |date= |website=NBC Sports History Page|publisher= |access-date= |quote=}}</ref> – Pacheco moved on to become a [[television]] boxing analyst, working for [[NBC]] and [[Univision]]. He became [[Showtime (TV network)|Showtime's]] featured boxing analyst in the early 1980s and continued his association with that network until his retirement from TV in the late 1990s, covering many memorable fights along the way. *[[Bob Papa]] – Papa has worked on [[Olympics on NBC|NBC]]'s coverage of the Olympics since [[1992 Summer Olympics|1992]], as he covered boxing at the most recent [[2008 Summer Olympics|Summer Olympics]]. *Jimmy Powers *[[Freddie Roach (boxing)|Freddie Roach]] *[[Kenny Rice]] – He's worked two [[Summer Olympic Games|Summer Olympics]]; boxing reporter (2004)<ref>[http://articles.latimes.com/2004/aug/08/sports/sp-olytvannounce8 LA Times "Behind The Mike"]</ref> and host of [[Equestrian at the Summer Olympics|Equestrian]] Competition (2008).<ref>[https://www.usatoday.com/sports/olympics/2008-07-16-nbc-announcers_N.htm USA Today "Olympic announcers for NBC and its affiliated cable TV channels"]</ref> *[[Fred Roggin]] – He served as a host for [[NBC Sports]] coverage of the [[2008 Summer Olympics]].<ref>[http://weblogs.baltimoresun.com/sports/mediumwell/blog/2008/07/your_nbc_olympics_lineup.html Medium Well: Your NBC Olympics lineup – A blog on sports media, news and networks – baltimoresun.com<!-- Bot generated title -->] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080803182204/http://weblogs.baltimoresun.com/sports/mediumwell/blog/2008/07/your_nbc_olympics_lineup.html |date=2008-08-03 }}</ref> *[[Tim Ryan (sportscaster)|Tim Ryan]] – When Ryan's contract with CBS expired in 1998, he moved to [[Fox Sports (USA)|Fox]] and NBC, where Ryan covered [[NFL on Fox|NFL games]] and tennis for Fox and [[Tennis on NBC|tennis]], alpine ski racing, equestrian events, and boxing for NBC. *[[Bob Haymes|Bob Stanton]] – In 1942, Haymes began work, under the name "Bob Stanton", for the radio show ''[[Gillette Cavalcade of Sports]]''. He continued with the program until 1946, when it was turned into a television show on [[NBC]].
==See also== *''[[The Contender (TV series)|The Contender]]'' *[[Stroh Brewing Company]] – For many years Stroh had received little television exposure because of an agreement between the major networks and [[Anheuser-Busch]] and [[Miller Brewing Company]] which allowed the two top brewers exclusive advertising rights. Stroh fought the agreement and in 1983 was allotted advertising time on [[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]]'s ''[[Monday Night Baseball]]'', on two [[NBC]] boxing events, and on other popular U.S. television sports shows.

'''Cassina S.p. A.''' is an [[Italy|Italian]] manufacturing company specialised in the creation of high-end [[designer furniture]].<ref>[http://goliath.ecnext.com/coms2/product-compint-0000775011-page.html Goliath Business Knowledge on demand]</ref>
==Origins== [[File:Carimate Chair Vico Magistretti Cassina Austin Calhoon Photograph.jpg|thumb|left|200px|Carimate Chair designed by Vico Magistretti in 1959 and produced by Cassina]] The "Amedeo Cassina" company was created by the brothers Cesare and Umberto Cassina in 1927 in [[Meda, Lombardy|Meda]], [[Brianza]], (Northern [[Italy]]).<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.treccani.it/enciclopedia/cesare-cassina/ |accessdate=January 22, 2015 |title=Cassina, Cesare |publisher=Treccani}}</ref> After the war, Cassina continued to expand in size and fame, with products which covered a broad range of furniture including: chairs, armchairs, tables, sofas and beds.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.architonic.com/pmabt/cassina/3100029 |title=Cassina Profile |publisher=Architonic |accessdate=January 22, 2015}}</ref>
==History== The company's transformation was bolstered further by commissions for cruise ships,<ref>{{cite book |url=https://books.google.ca/books?id=1kRJAQAAIAAJ&q=cruise+ships+Cassina&dq=cruise+ships+Cassina&hl=en&sa=X&ei=IkPBVNR20bbIBIyggcgN&ved=0CDsQ6AEwAg |accessdate=January 22, 2015 |title=Abitare |page=165 |publisher=Editrice Segesta |year=2008}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |url=https://books.google.ca/books?id=ekJQAAAAMAAJ&q=cruise+ships+Cassina&dq=cruise+ships+Cassina&hl=en&sa=X&ei=IkPBVNR20bbIBIyggcgN&ved=0CC8Q6AEwAA |accessdate=January 22, 2015 |page=94 |title=Custom-built: the concept of unique in Italian design |author=Silvana Annicchiarico |publisher=Charta |year=2003}}</ref> top end hotels and restaurants which accounted for a great part of the company's activity right up to the mid-sixties and beyond.<ref>{{cite web |page=6 |url=http://www.pfgroupcontract.com/uploads/object31/File/CASSINA%20CUSTOM%20INTERIORS.pdf |accessdate=January 22, 2015 |title=AN INTRODUCTION TO CASSINA CONTRACT DIVISION}}</ref>
In 1964 the "Cassina I Maestri" (Cassina Masters) Collection was born, with the acquisition of the rights to products designed by [[Le Corbusier]], Pierre Jeanneret and Charlotte Perriand, the most important names of 20th century design. These included the LC1, LC2,<ref>{{cite news |url=http://interiordesign.blog.nzz.ch/2014/11/28/das-doppeljubilaeum-von-le-corbusier/ |language=German |accessdate=January 22, 2015 |title=Das Doppeljubiläum von Le Corbusier |date=November 28, 2014 |author=Von Gastautor |publisher=Interior Design |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150122221208/http://interiordesign.blog.nzz.ch/2014/11/28/das-doppeljubilaeum-von-le-corbusier/# |archive-date=2015-01-22 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |year=1990 |title=Cassina I Maestri |url=https://books.google.ca/books?id=hAIyAQAAIAAJ&q=Cassina+I+Maestri+1964&dq=Cassina+I+Maestri+1964&hl=en&sa=X&ei=8kbBVPjiFoKqyATmuoCAAw&ved=0CCkQ6AEwAQ |publisher=Espresso |accessdate=January 22, 2015 |page=60}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |url=https://books.google.ca/books? |accessdate=January 22, 2015 |title=Blue Print |publisher=Wordsearch Limited |year=2007}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.dezeen.com/2011/01/22/authentic-wood-by-le-corbusier-at-cassina/ |accessdate=January 22, 2015 |publisher=Dezeen Magazine |date=January 22, 2011 |title=Authentic Wood by Le Corbusier at Cassina}}</ref> and LC3 armchairs,<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.post-gazette.com/life/homes/2011/05/18/Outdoor-living-Indoor-style-design-and-comfort-don-t-stop-at-the-back-door/stories/201105180259 |accessdate=January 22, 2015 |publisher=Pittsburgh Post-Gazette |date=May 18, 2011 |title=Outdoor living: Indoor style design and comfort don't stop at the back door |author=Patricia Sheridan}}</ref> and the LC4 chaise longue. Today Cassina is the exclusive worldwide licensee of the Le Corbusier designs.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.ft.com/intl/cms/s/2/c09530f4-1fbc-11e3-aa36-00144feab7de.html |publisher=Financial Times |accessdate=January 22, 2015 |date=September 20, 2013 |title=Design classic: The LC4 Chaise Longue by Le Corbusier |author=Kate Watson-Smyth}}</ref>
The "Cassina I Maestri" collection was widened in 1968 with the acquisition from Bauhaus-Archiv in Berlin of reproduction rights to some of the Bauhaus objects and in 1971 the designs of [[Gerrit Rietveld]], [[Frank Lloyd Wright]], and of [[Charles Rennie Mackintosh]] in 1972.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.palermotoday.it/economia/inaugurazione-cassina-arredamenti-palermo.html |language=Italian |publisher=Palermo Today |accessdate=January 22, 2015 |title=Cassina inaugura un nuovo branded space a Palermo |date=November 8, 2013}}</ref> The Masters collection continued with the re-issue in 1983 of furniture by Erik Gunner Asplund, the acquisition from the Frank Lloyd Wright Foundation of rights of reproduction (1986) of furniture by Frank Lloyd Wright, including the Barrel chair (1937), and, finally, in 2004 furniture by [[Charlotte Perriand]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.interioresminimalistas.com/2014/12/09/la-historia-de-cassina-y-el-diseno-traves-de-18-emblematica-sillas/ |accessdate=January 22, 2015 |publisher=Interiores Minimalistas |date=December 9, 2014 |title=La historia de Cassina y el diseño a través de una exposición con 18 de sus emblemáticas sillas |language=Spanish}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Sillas de diseño|url=http://www.vackart.es/29-sillas-de-diseno|publisher=www.vackart.es|accessdate=21 June 2016}}</ref>
The 1972, the New York MoMA exhibition, "Italy: the New Domestic Landscape" curated by [[Emilio Ambasz]] was co-sponsored Cassina.<ref>{{cite book |url=https://books.google.ca/books?id=WvGGAgAAQBAJ&pg=PA399 |page=399 |accessdate=January 22, 2014 |title=Encyclopedia of Contemporary Italian Culture |author=Gino Moliterno |publisher=Routledge |year=2002}}</ref> In 2005 Cassina was purchased by the Poltrona Frau Group.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.domusweb.it/en/design/2014/02/18/the_poltrona_frau_issue.html |publisher=Domus Web |date=February 18, 2014 |accessdate=January 22, 2015 |title=The Poltrona Frau Issue |author=Chiara Alessi}}</ref>
