{{Use dmy dates|date=April 2017}} [[File:Cynefin as of 1st June 2014.png|thumb|upright=1.1|Domains of the Cynefin framework; the dark domain in the centre is ''disorder''.]]{{anchor|diagram}} The '''Cynefin framework''' ({{IPAc-en|ˈ|k|ʌ|n|ᵻ|v|ɪ|n}} {{respell|KUN|iv|in}}) is a [[conceptual framework]] used to aid [[decision-making]]. Created in 1999 by [[Dave Snowden]] when he worked for [[IBM Global Services]], it has been described as a "[[Sensemaking|sense-making]] device". ''Cynefin'' is a [[Welsh language|Welsh]] word for ''habitat''.{{cite book|last1=Berger|first1=Jennifer Harvey|last2=Johnston|first2=Keith|title=Simple Habits for Complex Times|date=2015|publisher=Stanford University Press|location=Stanford, CA|at=236–237, n. 5|ref=harv}}{{pb}} {{cite web|url=http://www.geiriadur.net/index.php?page=ateb&term=cynefin&direction=we&type=all&whichpart=beginning|title=Cynefin|work=Welsh-English / English-Welsh On-line Dictionary|publisher=University of Wales|accessdate=24 November 2016}} Cynefin offers five decision-making contexts or "domains"—''obvious'' (known until 2014 as ''simple''),{{sfnp|Berger|Johnston|2015|loc=237, n. 7}} ''complicated'', ''complex'', ''chaotic'', and ''disorder''—that help managers to identify how they perceive situations and make sense of their own and other people's behaviour.{{efn|name=SnowdenBoonedomains}} The framework draws on research into [[systems theory]], [[Complexity theory and organizations|complexity theory]], [[network theory]] and [[Learning theory (education)|learning theories]].{{cite book|last1=Williams|first1=Bob|last2=Hummelbrunner|first2=Richard|title=Systems Concepts in Action: A Practitioner's Toolkit|date=2010|publisher=Stanford University Press|location=Stanford, CA|pages=10, 163–164|ref=harv}} ==Background== ===Terminology=== The idea of the Cynefin framework is that it offers decision-makers a "sense of place" from which to view their perceptions. ''Cynefin'' is a Welsh word meaning ''habitat'', ''haunt'', ''acquainted'', ''familiar''. Snowden uses the term to refer to the idea that we all have connections, such as tribal, religious and geographical, of which we may not be aware.{{cite web|url=http://www.bangor.ac.uk/psychology/news/honorary-professorship-for-david-j-snowden-22486|title=Honorary Professorship for David J Snowden|date=15 April 2015|publisher=[[Bangor University]] School of Psychology}} It has been compared to the [[Māori language|Maori]] word ''turangawaewae'', meaning a place to stand.{{sfnp|Berger|Johnston|2015|loc=236–237, n. 5}} ===History=== Snowden, then of IBM Global Services, began work on a Cynefin model in 1999 to help manage [[intellectual capital]] within the company.Snowden, David (1999). "Liberating Knowledge", in ''Liberating Knowledge''. CBI Business Guide. London: Caspian Publishing.{{efn|Snowden (2000): "An early form of the Cynefin model using different labels for the dimension extremes and quadrant spaces was developed as a means of understanding the reality of intellectual capital management within IBM Global Services (Snowden 1999a)."{{cite book|last1=Snowden|first1=Dave|editor1-last=Despres|editor1-first=Charles|editor2-last=Chauvel|editor2-first=Daniele|title=Knowledge Horizons|date=2000|publisher=Butterworth–Heinemann|location=Boston|at=[https://books.google.com/books?id=evngN1vTO-8C&pg=PA239 239]|ref=harv|chapter=The Social Ecology of Knowledge Management}}Also see Snowden, Dave. [http://citeseerx.ist.psu.edu/viewdoc/download?doi=10.1.1.196.3058&rep=rep1&type=pdf "Cynefin, A Sense of Time and Place: an Ecological Approach to Sense Making and Learning in Formal and Informal Communities"]. citeseerx.ist.psu.edu.}}{{efn|name=SnowdenPauleen|Snowden, Pauleen, and Jansen van Vuuren (2011): "The framework was initially used in Snowden's early work in knowledge management, but now extends to aspects of leadership, strategy, cultural change, customer relationship management and more (Kurtz and Snowden 2003; Snowden and Boone 2007). The framework is particularly effective in helping decision-makers to make sense of complex problems, providing new ways of approaching intractable problems and allowing the emergence of shared understandings from collective groups."Snowden, Dave; Pauleen, David J.; Jansen van Vuuren, Sally (2016). "Knowledge Management and the Individual: It's Nothing Personal", in David J. Pauleen and Gorman, G. E. (eds.). ''Personal Knowledge Management''. Abingdon: Routledge 2011, 116.}} He continued developing it as European director of IBM's Institute of Knowledge Management,{{harvnb|Snowden|2000|loc=[https://books.google.com/books?id=evngN1vTO-8C&pg=PA237 237–266]}}; Snowden, Dave (May 2002). [https://web.archive.org/web/20030916092840/http://www-1.ibm.com/services/files/complex.pdf "Complex Acts of Knowing: Paradox and Descriptive Self Awareness"], ''Journal of Knowledge Management'', 6(2), 100–111. {{doi|10.1108/13673270210424639}} and later as founder and director of the IBM Cynefin Centre for Organizational Complexity, established in 2002.[http://alumni.media.mit.edu/~brooks/storybiz/kurtz.pdf Kurtz and Snowden (2003)], 483; [https://web.archive.org/web/20020614001545/http://www-1.ibm.com/services/cynefin/ "The Cynefin Centre for Organisational Complexity"], IBM, archived 14 June 2002; [https://web.archive.org/web/20020810111101/http://www-1.ibm.com/services/cynefin/membership.html "Membership"], IBM, archived 10 August 2002. Snowden and Cynthia Kurtz, an IBM researcher, described the framework in detail the following year in a paper, "The new dynamics of strategy: Sense-making in a complex and complicated world", published in ''IBM Systems Journal''.{{sfn|Williams|Hummelbrunner|2010|loc=10, 163–164}}Quiggin, Thomas (2007). "Interview with Mr. Dave Snowden of Cognitive Edge", ''Seeing the Invisible: National Security Intelligence in an Uncertain Age''. Singapore: World Scientific Publishing Co., [https://books.google.com/books?id=6QCcuV1seUcC&pg=PA212 212]. The Cynefin Centre—a network of members and partners from industry, government and academia—began operating independently of IBM in 2004.[http://www.kmworld.com/Articles/News/News-Analysis/The-Cynefin-Centre-Life-after-IBM-14542.aspx "The Cynefin Centre: Life after IBM"], ''KM World'', 14(7), July/August 2005. In 2007 Snowden and Mary E. Boone described the Cynefin framework in the ''[[Harvard Business Review]]''.Snowden, David J.; Boone, Mary E. (November 2007). [https://hbr.org/2007/11/a-leaders-framework-for-decision-making "A Leader's Framework for Decision Making"]. ''Harvard Business Review'', 69–76. {{PMID|18159787}} Their paper, "A Leader's Framework for Decision Making", won them an "Outstanding Practitioner-Oriented Publication in OB" award from the [[Academy of Management]]'s Organizational Behavior division.[http://obweb.org/index.php/awards/publication-awards/#award2 "Outstanding Practitioner-Oriented Publication in OB"], obweb.org. == Domains{{anchor|Domains}}== {{See also|Problem structuring methods#Types of situations that call for PSMs}} [[File:Cynefin framework by Edwin Stoop.jpg|upright=2.5|thumb|centre|Sketch of the Cynefin framework, by Edwin Stoop]] ===Overview=== Cynefin offers four decision-making contexts or "domains": ''simple, complicated, complex, chaotic'', and a centre of ''disorder''.{{efn|Williams and Hummelbrunner (2010): " ... Cynefin identifies four behaviors a situation can display: simple, complicated, complex, and chaotic. This terminology is not new; the systems literature has used it for decades. However, in Cynefin the behaviors and the properties that underpin these four states are not entirely drawn from systems theories or even theories of chaos and complexity. Cynefin draws heavily on network theory, learning theories, and third-generation knowledgement management.{{pb}}"Crucially, compared with many network and company approaches, Cynefin also takes an epistemological as well as an ontological stance. Similar to the [[Soft systems methodology|Soft Systems]] and [[Critical systems thinking|Critical Systems]] traditions ... Cynefin explores how people perceive and learn from situations."{{sfn|Williams|Hummelbrunner|2010|loc=10, 163–164}}}} The domain names have changed over the years. Kurtz and Snowden (2003) called them ''known, knowable, complex, and chaotic''. Snowden and Boone (2007) changed ''known'' and ''knowable'' to ''simple'' and ''complicated''.{{efn|name=SnowdenBoonedomains|Snowden and Boone (2007): "The framework sorts the issues facing leaders into five contexts defined by the nature of the relationship between cause and effect. Four of these—simple, complicated, complex, and chaotic—require leaders to diagnose situations and to act in contextually appropriate ways. The fifth—disorder—applies when it is unclear which of the other four contexts is predominant."}} Since 2014 Snowden has used ''obvious'' in place of ''simple''.{{sfnp|Berger|Johnston|2015|loc=237, n. 7}} The domains offer a "sense of place" from which to analyse behaviour and make decisions.Browning, Larry; Latoza, Roderick (31 December 2005). [https://journal.emergentpublications.com/article/the-use-of-narrative-to-understand-and-respond-to-complexity-a-comparative-analysis-of-the-cynefin-and-weickian-models/pdf/ "The use of narrative to understand and respond to complexity: A comparative analysis of the Cynefin and Weickian models"], ''Emergence: Complexity and Organization'', 7(3–4): 32–39 (last modified: 23 November 2016). The domains on the right, ''simple''/''obvious'' and ''complicated'', are "ordered": cause and effect are known or can be discovered. The domains on the left, ''complex'' and ''chaotic'', are "unordered": cause and effect can be deduced only with hindsight or not at all.Koskela, Lauri; Kagioglou, Mike (2006). [http://www.iglc.net/conferences/2005/papers/session01/05_059_Koskela_Kagioglou.pdf "On the Metaphysics of Production"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080723143154/http://www.iglc.net/conferences/2005/papers/session01/05_059_Koskela_Kagioglou.pdf |date=23 July 2008 }}. ''Proceedings of the 13th Annual Conference on Lean Construction'', Sydney, Australia, July 2005 (37–45), 42–43. ===Simple / Obvious === [[File:Cynefin framework, February 2011 (2).jpeg|thumb|Since 2014 Snowden has called the ''simple'' domain ''obvious''.{{sfnp|Berger|Johnston|2015|loc=237, n. 7}}]] The ''simple''/''obvious'' domain represents the "known knowns". This means that there are rules in place (or [[best practice]]), the situation is stable, and the relationship between cause and effect is clear: if you do X, expect Y. The advice in such a situation is to "sense–categorize–respond": establish the facts ("sense"), categorize, then respond by following the rule or applying best practice. Snowden and Boone (2007) offer the example of loan-payment processing. An employee identifies the problem (for example, a borrower has paid less than required), categorizes it (reviews the loan documents), and responds (follows the terms of the loan). According to [[Thomas A. Stewart]],
This is the domain of legal structures, standard operating procedures, practices that are proven to work. Never draw to an [[Draw (poker)#Inside straight draw|inside straight]]. Never lend to a client whose monthly payments exceed 35 percent of gross income. Never end the meeting without asking for the sale. Here, decision-making lies squarely in the realm of reason: Find the proper rule and apply it.{{cite news|last1=Stewart|first1=Thomas A.|title=How to Think With Your Gut|url=http://www.business2.com:80/articles/mag/0,1640,44584%7c2,FF.html|work=Business 2.0|date=November 2002|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20021105114814/http://www.business2.com:80/articles/mag/0,1640,44584%7c2,FF.html|archivedate=5 November 2002|pages=4–5|dead-url=yes}}
Snowden and Boone write that managers should beware of forcing situations into this domain by over-simplifying, by "entrained thinking" (being blind to new ways of thinking), or by becoming complacent. When success breeds complacency ("best practice is, by definition, past practice"), there can be a catastrophic clockwise shift into the chaotic domain. They recommend that leaders provide a communication channel, if necessary an anonymous one, so that dissenters (for example, within a workforce) can warn about complacency. ===Complicated=== The ''complicated'' domain consists of the "known unknowns". The relationship between cause and effect requires analysis or expertise; there are a range of right answers. The framework recommends "sense–analyze–respond": assess the facts, analyze, and apply the appropriate good operating practice. According to Stewart: "Here it is possible to work rationally toward a decision, but doing so requires refined judgment and expertise. ... This is the province of engineers, surgeons, intelligence analysts, lawyers, and other experts. Artificial intelligence copes well here: [[Deep Blue (chess computer)|Deep Blue]] plays chess as if it were a complicated problem, looking at every possible sequence of moves." ===Complex=== The ''complex'' domain represents the "unknown unknowns". Cause and effect can only be deduced in retrospect, and there are no right answers. "Instructive patterns ... can emerge," write Snowden and Boone, "if the leader conducts experiments that are safe to fail." Cynefin calls this process "probe–sense–respond". Hard insurance cases are one example. "Hard cases ... need human underwriters," Stewart writes, "and the best all do the same thing: Dump the file and spread out the contents." Stewart identifies battlefields, markets, ecosystems and corporate cultures as complex systems that are "impervious to a reductionist, take-it-apart-and-see-how-it-works approach, because your very actions change the situation in unpredictable ways." ===Chaotic=== In the ''chaotic'' domain, cause and effect are unclear.{{efn|Cynefin uses ''chaotic'' in the ordinary sense, rather than in the sense used in [[chaos theory]].{{sfnp|Berger|Johnston|2015|loc=237, n. 11}}}} Events in this domain are "too confusing to wait for a knowledge-based response", writes Patrick Lambe. "Action—''any'' action—is the first and only way to respond appropriately."Lambe, Patrick (2007). ''Organising Knowledge: Taxonomies, Knowledge and Organisational Effectiveness''. Oxford: Chandos Publishing, 136. In this context, managers "act–sense–respond": ''act'' to establish order; ''sense'' where stability lies; ''respond'' to turn the chaotic into the complex. Snowden and Boone write:
In the chaotic domain, a leader’s immediate job is not to discover patterns but to staunch the bleeding. A leader must first act to establish order, then sense where stability is present and from where it is absent, and then respond by working to transform the situation from chaos to complexity, where the identification of emerging patterns can both help prevent future crises and discern new opportunities. Communication of the most direct top-down or broadcast kind is imperative; there’s simply no time to ask for input.
The [[September 11 attacks]] were an example of the ''chaotic'' category. Stewart offers others: "the firefighter whose gut makes him turn left or the trader who instinctively sells when the news about the stock seems too good to be true." One [[Crisis management|crisis executive]] said of the [[Enron scandal|collapse of Enron]]: "People were afraid. ... Decision-making was paralyzed. ... You've got to be quick and decisive—make little steps you know will succeed, so you can begin to tell a story that makes sense." Snowden and Boone give the example of the 1993 [[Brown's Chicken massacre]] in [[Palatine]], Illinois—when robbers murdered seven employees in Brown's Chicken and Pasta restaurant—as a situation in which local police faced all the domains. Deputy Police Chief Walt Gasior had to act immediately to stem the early panic (''chaotic''), while keeping the department running (''simple''), calling in experts (''complicated''), and maintaining community confidence in the following weeks (''complex''). ===Disorder / Confusion=== The dark ''disorder'' domain in the centre represents situations where there is no clarity about which of the other domains apply. By definition it is hard to see when this domain applies. "Here, multiple perspectives jostle for prominence, factional leaders argue with one another, and cacophony rules", write Snowden and Boone. "The way out of this realm is to break down the situation into constituent parts and assign each to one of the other four realms. Leaders can then make decisions and intervene in contextually appropriate ways." ===Moving through domains=== As knowledge increases, there is a "clockwise drift" from ''chaotic'' through ''complex'' and ''complicated'' to ''simple''. Similarly, a "buildup of biases", complacency or lack of maintenance can cause a "catastrophic failure": a clockwise movement from ''simple'' to ''chaotic'', represented by the "fold" between those domains. There can be counter-clockwise movement as people die and knowledge is forgotten, or as new generations question the rules; and a counter-clockwise push from ''chaotic'' to ''simple'' can occur when a lack of order causes rules to be imposed suddenly. == Applications and reception== [[File:Leader's Framework for Policing Protest.gif|thumb|upright=1.2|Using the Cynefin framework to analyse policing of the [[Occupy movement]] in the United States]] Cynefin was used by its IBM developers in policy-making, product development, market creation, [[supply chain management]], [[Brand management|branding]] and [[customer relations]].{{cite journal|last1=Kurtz |first1=Cynthia F. |last2=Snowden |first2=David J. |title=The new dynamics of strategy: Sense-making in a complex and complicated world |journal=IBM Systems Journal |date=2003 |volume=42 |issue=3 |pages=462–483 |doi=10.1147/sj.423.0462 |url=http://alumni.media.mit.edu/~brooks/storybiz/kurtz.pdf |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060918205828/http://alumni.media.mit.edu/~brooks/storybiz/kurtz.pdf |archivedate=18 September 2006 |df= }} Later uses include analysing the impact of religion on policymaking within the [[George W. Bush]] administration,{{cite journal | first = Louisa-Jayne | last = O'Neill | year = 2004 | url = http://emergentpublications.com/eco/ECO_other/Issue_6_1-2_20_FM.pdf | title = Faith and decision-making in the Bush presidency: The God elephant in the middle of America's livingroom | journal = Emergence: Complexity and Organisation | volume = 6 | number = 1/2 | pages = 149–156}} [[emergency management]],{{cite journal | last1 = French | first1 = Simon | last2 = Niculae | first2 = Carmen |doi=10.2202/1547-7355.1108| url = http://www.degruyter.com/view/j/jhsem.2005.2.1/jhsem.2005.2.1.1108/jhsem.2005.2.1.1108.xml | title = Believe in the Model: Mishandle the Emergency | journal = Journal of Homeland Security and Emergency Management | volume = 2 | issue = 1 | year = March 2005}} [[network science]] and the military,Verdon, John (July 2005). [http://pubs.drdc.gc.ca/PDFS/unc42/p524061.pdf "Transformation in the CF: Concept towards a theory of Human Network-Enabled"]. Ottawa: National Defence, Directory of Strategic Human Resources. the management of food-chain risks,{{cite journal | date = July 2006 | last1 = Shepherd | first1 = Richard | last2 = Barker | first2 = Gary | last3 = French | first3 = Simon | last4 = Hart | first4 = Andy | last5 = Maule | first5 = John | last6 = Cassidy | first6 = Angela | title = Managing Food Chain Risks: Integrating Technical and Stakeholder Perspectives on Uncertainty | journal = Journal of Agricultural Economics | volume = 57 | issue = 2 | pages = 313–327 | url = http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/j.1477-9552.2006.00054.x/abstract | doi=10.1111/j.1477-9552.2006.00054.x |display-authors=3}} [[homeland security]] in the United States,Bellavita, Christopher (October 2006). [https://www.hsaj.org/articles/680 "Shape Patterns, Not Programs"], ''Homeland Security Affairs'', II(3), 1–21. [[agile software development]],{{cite journal | last = Pelrine | first = Joseph | date = March 2011 | url = http://www.metaprog.com/downloads/ECO.pdf | title = On Understanding Software Agility: A Social Complexity Point Of View |journal = Emergence: Complexity & Organization | volume = 13 | issue = 1/2| pages =26}} and policing the [[Occupy Movement]] in the United States.Geron, Stephen Max (March 2014). [http://calhoun.nps.edu/bitstream/handle/10945/41382/14Mar_Geron_Max.pdf "21st Century strategies for policing protest"] (pdf), Naval Postgraduate School. It has also been used in health-care research, including to examine the complexity of care in the British [[National Health Service]],{{cite journal | last1 = Mark | first1 = Annabelle L. | year = 2006 | title = Notes from a Small Island: Researching Organisational Behaviour in Healthcare from a UK Perspective | url = | journal = Journal of Organizational Behavior | volume = 27 | issue = 7| pages = 851–867 | doi = 10.1002/job.414 | jstor = 4093874}} the nature of knowledge in health care,{{cite journal | last1 = Sturmberg | first1 = Joachim P. | last2 = Martin | first2 = Carmel M. | year = October 2008 | title = Knowing – in Medicine | url = | journal = Journal of Evaluation in Clinical Practice | volume = 14 | issue = 5| pages = 767–770 | doi = 10.1111/j.1365-2753.2008.01011.x | pmid = 19018908}} and the fight against HIV/AIDs in South Africa.Burman, Christopher J.; Aphane, Marota A. (September 2016). "Leadership emergence: the application of the Cynefin framework during a bio-social HIV/AIDS risk-reduction pilot", ''African Journal of AIDS Research'', 15(3), 249–260. {{doi|10.2989/16085906.2016.1198821}} {{PMID|27681149}} In 2017 the RAND Corporation used the Cynefin framework in a discussion of theories and models of decision making.Cox, Kate; Strang, Lucy; Sondergaard, Susan; and Monsalve, Cristina Gonzalez (2017). [https://www.rand.org/pubs/research_reports/RR1827.html "Understanding how organisations ensure that their decision making is fair"]. Santa Monica, CA: RAND Corporation. Criticism of Cynefin includes that the framework is difficult and confusing, needs a more rigorous foundation, and covers too limited a selection of possible contexts.Firestone, Joseph M.; McElroy, Mark W. (2011). ''Key Issues in the New Knowledge Management''. Abingdon: Routledge, 132–133 (first published 2003). Another criticism is that terms such as ''known, knowable, sense,'' and ''categorize'' are ambiguous.{{sfn|Williams|Hummelbrunner|2010|loc=182}} == See also == {{Div col|colwidth=22em}} * [[I-Space (conceptual framework)]] * [[Inquiry]] * [[Karl E. Weick]] * [[Narrative inquiry]] * [[SECI model of knowledge dimensions]] * [[There are known knowns]] * [[Uncertainty]] * [[Volatility, uncertainty, complexity and ambiguity]] * [[VPEC-T]] {{Div col end}} == Notes == {{notelist|25em}} == References == {{reflist|25em}} [[Category:IBM]] [[Category:Knowledge management]] [[Category:Management consulting]]

{{More footnotes|date=July 2011}} '''Ernest Walter Saunders''' (born 21 October 1935) is a British former business manager, best known as one of the [[Guinness share-trading fraud|"Guinness Four"]], a group of businessmen who attempted fraudulently to manipulate the share price of the [[Guinness]] company. He was sentenced to five years' imprisonment, but released after 10 months as he was believed to be suffering from [[Alzheimer's disease]], which is incurable. He subsequently made a full recovery.
==Personal life== He was born '''Ernest Walter Schleyer''' in [[Austria]] and moved to the United Kingdom in 1938 when his parents - a [[Jewish]] gynaecologist and an Austrian mother -<ref>Ivan Fallon & James Srodes, ''Takeovers'', H. Hamilton (1987), p. 197</ref> emigrated to escape Nazi rule. He was educated at [[Emmanuel College, Cambridge]]. He married Carole Ann Stephing in 1963, and has two sons and one daughter.
==Professional life== He had a career in management with [[GlaxoSmithKline|Beecham]], [[GUS (retailer)|Great Universal Stores]] and [[Nestlé]] before becoming chief executive of [[Guinness]] plc (now a part of [[Diageo]] plc) in 1981, remaining in the position until 1986. He was renowned for his ruthless cost-cutting efficiency, earning from his employees the sobriquet 'Deadly Ernest'.
Under his charge, early in 1986, Guinness plc launched a friendly takeover bid for Edinburgh-based [[Distillers Company]] plc, which was being stalked by a hostile bidder. This was effected by quietly boosting the Guinness share price. Subsequent to the bid, which resulted in success for Guinness, Saunders was charged (along with [[Jack Lyons (financier)|Jack Lyons]], [[Anthony Parnes]] and [[Gerald Ronson]]) and convicted on 27 August 1990 of counts of conspiracy to contravene section 13(1)(a)(i) of the Prevention of Fraud (Investments) Act 1958, false accounting and theft, in relation to dishonest conduct in a share support operation (see [[Guinness share-trading fraud]]). A series of appeals was finally dismissed in December 2002, although a ruling by the [[European Court of Human Rights]] in ''[[Saunders v. the United Kingdom]]'' declared that the defendants were denied a fair trial by being compelled to provide potentially self-incriminatory information to [[Department of Trade and Industry (United Kingdom)|Department of Trade and Industry]] (DTI) inspectors which was then used as primary evidence against them. This breached their privilege against self-incrimination.
While there was no suggestion that Saunders himself sought to or actually did profit from these offences in an immediate or direct manner, the allegation was that they were committed to increase the likelihood of their company's takeover bid succeeding. His board of directors at Guinness plc was not informed of, and had not sanctioned, his arrangements, which included indemnities for unknowable amounts. He had passed $100 million to the American [[Ivan Boesky]] to invest shortly before Boesky's prosecution and imprisonment for [[insider trading]], and following that investigation Saunders' plans were revealed to the DTI in Britain.<ref name="fight for acquittal">{{cite news | last=Verdin | first=Mike| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/business/1723136.stm | title=Guinness Four fail in fight for acquittal | publisher= BBC News| date=21 December 2001 | accessdate=5 September 2012 }}</ref>
A DTI report described him as a man who did "unjustifiable favours for friends and himself".<ref name=highflying>{{cite news | url=http://www.scotsman.com/news/life-and-high-flying-times-of-four-partners-in-crime-1-590390 | title=Life and high-flying times of four partners in crime| newspaper=The Scotsman| date=22 December 2001 |accessdate=5 September 2012}}</ref>
==Sentence and appeal==
Saunders appealed against his prison sentence of five years and three expert witnesses appeared at the [[Court of Appeal of England and Wales|Appeal Court]]. A consultant neurologist acting for the Crown, Dr Perkins, insisted that Saunders was suffering from depression rather than [[Alzheimer's disease]].<ref name="Shepherd">{{cite news |first=John |last=Shepherd |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/forget-alzheimers--saunders-1388784.html |title=Forget Alzheimer's – Saunders |date=30 December 1994 |work=The Independent }}</ref> One of the other expert witnesses, another neurologist, used brain scans and other evidence to indicate that Saunders brain was abnormally small for a man of his age, an observation which he said was consistent with a brain disease diagnosis.<ref>Jeremy Warner [https://www.independent.co.uk/voices/profile-ernest-saunders-out-of-jail-and-back-in-business-1347932.html "Profile: Ernest Saunders; Out of jail and back in business"], ''The Independent'', 18 May 1996</ref>
On 16 May 1991, the sentence was reduced to two and a half years. Lord Justice Neill said that he was satisfied that Saunders was suffering from pre-senile dementia associated with Alzheimer's disease, which is incurable.<ref name="fight for acquittal"/> The decision was based on evidence from Dr Patrick Gallwey, a forensic pathologist, that Saunders was unable to recite three numbers backwards, was unable to use a door and his assertion that [[Gerald Ford]] rather than [[George W. Bush|George Bush]] was the current President of the United States.<ref name="Shepherd"/><ref name="Boggan">{{cite web |first=Steve |last=Boggan |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/lucky-ernie-from-dazed-old-man-to-rich-adviser-1314871.html |title=Lucky Ernie: from dazed old man to rich adviser |date=17 December 1996 |work=The Independent }}</ref>
Because of his apparent illness, Saunders was released from [[Ford Open Prison]] on 28 June 1991 having served only ten months of his sentence. (He would normally have been expected to have served 15 months of the 30-month sentence). After his release, he recovered from the symptoms which had led to the diagnosis.<ref name=highflying/> Saunders himself claimed in 1994 that he was never diagnosed with Alzheimer's,<ref name="Shepherd"/> When asked by ''[[The Independent]]'' in 1996, Dr Gallwey commented: "In the early stages of Alzheimer's or pre-senile dementia, it can be very difficult to make a diagnosis, so we did not make one; we expressed worries about it."<ref name="Boggan"/> It has been suggested he was in reality suffering from memory loss caused by stress.<ref>Chris Blackhurst [https://www.independent.co.uk/news/the-renaissance-man-1256097.html "The Renaissance man"], ''The Independent on Sunday'', 15 June 1997</ref>
==Later life== Since apparently recovering from Alzheimer's, Saunders has worked as a business consultant, including advising mobile phone retailer [[Carphone Warehouse]] from its early days until prior to its flotation. [[Charles Dunstone]], the Chief executive of Carphone Warehouse, said: "We were young guys who didn’t know what we were doing. He made us think about the questions we ought to ask or the information we ought to look at."
He was later appointed chairman of the executive committee of a US-based multinational petrol credit-card company, Harpur-Gelco.
Saunders also acted as a consultant to Seed International Ltd, a company based in the Cayman Islands. Seed offered investments in a variety of fields including wine, property, oil and gas exploration through Ocean International Marketing, their sales subsidiary with offices in Rotterdam.
== See also == * [[Guinness plc v Saunders]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
==Further reading== * Nick Kochan and [[Hugh Pym]] – ''The Guinness Affair: Anatomy of a Scandal'' (1987) {{ISBN|0-7470-2610-6}} * Adrian Milne and James Long – ''Guinness Scandal: Biggest Story in the City's History'' (1990) {{ISBN|0-7181-3445-1}} * James Saunders – ''Nightmare: Ernest Saunders and the Guinness Affair'' (Arrow Books, 1988) {{ISBN|0-09-974480-5}} * Jonathan Guinness – ''Requiem for a Family Business'' (Macmillan 1997). * Gerald Ronson and Jeffrey Robinson – ''Gerald Ronson – Leading from the Front: My Story: The Gerald Ronson Story'' (2009)

{{Use dmy dates|date=March 2014}} {{Infobox person | name = Hansjörg Wyss | image = Hansjorg Wyss profile image.png | caption = Hansjörg Wyss (2015) | birth_date = {{birth date and age|df=yes|1935|09|19}} | birth_place = [[Bern]], Switzerland | death_date = | death_place = | residence = [[Wilson, Wyoming]], U.S. | alma_mater = [[Swiss Federal Institute of Technology Zurich]]
[[Harvard Business School]] | occupation = Former [[CEO]] of [[Synthes]]
[[Chairman]] of The Wyss Foundation and The HJW Foundation | networth = [[United States dollar|$]]5.6 billion
(May 2017){{cite web|title=Hansjoerg Wyss|url=https://www.forbes.com/profile/hansjoerg-wyss|website=Forbes|accessdate=19 May 2017}} | children = [[Amy Wyss]] }} '''Hansjörg Wyss''' (born 19 September 1935) is a Swiss entrepreneur, businessman, and philanthropist. He is the founder and was president, then chairman, of Synthes USA, until its sale in 2012. Wyss lives in Wyoming and has supported philanthropic causes relating to environmental protection, social justice, and science. His contributions led to the establishment of the [[Wyss Institute for Biologically Inspired Engineering]] at [[Harvard University]] in 2009 and he created the Wyss Foundation, which aims to conserve natural environments, including public lands in the [[Western United States]], [[Africa]], and [[South America]]. As of 2017, Wyss has a net worth of US$5.6 billion, according to ''[[Forbes]]''.Wilkinson, Tara Loader. [http://www.efinancialnews.com/story/2008-10-08/switzerlands-second-richest-man-makes-big-donation-to-harvard Switzerland's second richest man makes big donation to Harvard], ''[[Financial News|Wealth Bulletin]]'', 8 October 2008; retrieved 15 October 2008. ==Early life and career== Wyss was born in [[Bern]], Switzerland in 1935. His father sold mechanical calculators and his mother was a homemaker. He was raised in an apartment with two sisters. After receiving a master's degree in Civil and Structural Engineering from the [[Swiss Federal Institute of Technology Zurich]] in 1959,{{cite news|title=Wyss May Top Bertarelli as Richest Swiss Man in Synthes Sale|author=Allison Connolly |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2011-04-19/wyss-may-replace-bertarelli-as-richest-swiss-man-in-synthes-sale|work=Bloomberg.com|date=20 April 2011|accessdate=26 June 2015}} Wyss earned an [[MBA]] from [[Harvard Business School]] in 1965. Following that, he worked in various positions in the textile industry, including plant engineer and project manager for [[Chrysler]] in Pakistan, Turkey, and the Philippines.{{cite web|url=https://www.alumni.hbs.edu/stories/Pages/story-bulletin.aspx?num=2000|title=Hansjörg Wyss, MBA 1965|date=1 January 2007|work=alumni.hbs.edu|publisher=[[Harvard Business School]]|accessdate=25 June 2015}} Wyss also worked in the steel industry in [[City of Brussels|Brussels, Belgium]]. During his time working in that industry, Wyss ran a side business selling airplanes. Through one sale, he met a surgeon who had co-founded Swiss [[medical device]] manufacturer [[Synthes]].{{cite news|title=Legal troubles for local billionaire|author=Miriam Hill|url=http://www.philly.com/philly/business/20091206_Legal_troubles_for_local_billionaire.html|work=[[Philadelphia Media Network|Philly.com]]|date=6 December 2009|accessdate=9 July 2015}} After that meeting, Wyss spent two years learning about the medical device industry. He founded and became president of Synthes USA in 1977. ==Synthes USA== {{main|Synthes}} In 1977, Wyss founded and became president of Synthes USA, the U.S. division of Switzerland-based [[Synthes]] medical device manufacturer making internal screws and plates for broken bones. In an early initiative, Wyss opened a Synthes USA manufacturing plant in Colorado. Prior to that, another Switzerland company manufactured Synthes' devices and exported them to the U.S. Under Wyss' control, the U.S. division expanded its sales team and trained surgeons how to use its products. Wyss served as Synthes' worldwide CEO and chairman until his resignation as CEO in 2007. He maintained his post as company chairman until [[Johnson & Johnson]] acquired Synthes in 2012.{{cite news|title=Synthes Sale Creates $8.7 Billion Man|author=Matthew Herper|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/matthewherper/2011/04/27/synthes-sale-creates-8-7-billion-man|work=[[Forbes]]|date=27 April 2011|accessdate=13 October 2015}}{{cite news|title=Johnson & Johnson completes $20B takeover of Synthes|author=John George|url=http://www.bizjournals.com/philadelphia/news/2012/06/14/johnson-johnson-completes-20b.html|newspaper=[[American City Business Journals|Philadelphia Business Journal]]|date=14 June 2012|accessdate=21 July 2015}} During his tenure, Wyss said discussions of new products made up one-third of board meetings. A manager assigned to the Norian project testified before a grand jury that "for somebody who is at his level and his level of success, I would say he [Wyss] has a surprising amount of contact with what's going on." Staff recalled meetings in which he intensively probed their projects. In 2009, top executives at Synthes were indicted by U.S. Attorneys for Eastern Pennsylvania for using an untested calcium-phosphate-based bone cement on human patients without the authorization from the [[Food and Drug Administration]], which resulted in the deaths of three people.[http://www.washingtonexaminer.com/three-people-died-in-illegal-human-experiments-carried-out-by-john-podesta-backers-firm/article/2551139 "Three people died in illegal human experiments carried out by John Podesta backer's firm"], washingtonexaminer.com; accessed 21 October 2015. Wyss was not indicted but four of Synthes' top executives were convicted and sentenced to prison terms.[http://fortune.com/2012/09/18/bad-to-the-bone-a-medical-horror-story "Bad to the Bone - a Medical Horror Story"], fortune.com, 18 September 2012. In 2012 Wyss sold the company for $21.3 billion in cash and stock to [[Johnson & Johnson]].Wilkinson, Tara Loader. [http://www.efinancialnews.com/story/2008-10-08/switzerlands-second-richest-man-makes-big-donation-to-harvard Switzerland's second richest man makes big donation to Harvard], ''[[Financial News|Wealth Bulletin]]'', 8 October 2008; retrieved 15 October 2008. ==Philanthropy== According to ''[[Forbes]]'', Wyss is "among the most [[philanthropy|philanthropic]] people in the world". Between 2004 and 2008, ''[[Businessweek]]'' estimated that Wyss personally donated nearly USD$277 million. His giving has increased since the sale of Synthes in 2012 and in 2013 he signed [[The Giving Pledge]], agreeing to give away the majority of his fortune.{{cite news|title=Wyss, Yet Another Big Philanthropist, Turns to the Oceans|author=Tate Williams|url=http://www.insidephilanthropy.com/home/2014/11/4/wyss-yet-another-big-philanthropist-turns-to-the-oceans.html|work=Inside Philanthropy|date=4 November 2014|accessdate=9 July 2015}} The assets of his charitable foundations equal nearly $2 billion. His primary philanthropic causes are the [[Environmental movement|environment]], [[social justice]], and [[science]], but he frequently contributes to historic projects and [[Europe]]an museums. The Wyss Foundation, a charitable organization he founded, has awarded grants for environmental protection as well as to [[Progressivism|progressive]] policy organizations, including the [[Center for Budget and Policy Priorities]], [[Health Leads]], and the [[Constitutional Accountability Center]]. ===Environmental protection=== As of 2017, Wyss and the Wyss Foundation have donated more than $350 million to [[environmental protection]], including [[Conservation (ethic)|conservation]] of national forests and other public lands in the [[Western United States]].{{cite news|title='Quietly philanthropic' tycoon makes his mark in the West|author=Phil Taylor|url=http://www.eenews.net/stories/1060015651|work=[[Environment & Energy Publishing]]|date=24 May 2015|accessdate=25 June 2015}} In October 2018 Wyss published an article in the [[New York Times]] stating that he was contributing 1 billion dollars to environmental causes.{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/10/31/opinion/earth-biodiversity-conservation-billion-dollars.html|title=We Have to Save the Planet. So I’m Donating $1 Billion.|publisher=''New York Times''|accessdate=2 November 2018}} Wyss has stated that he became passionate about the American West and land preservation after visiting the U.S. in 1958 as a student and taking a summer job as a [[Surveying|surveyor]] with the Colorado Highway Department.{{cite news|title=Bernese billionaire works to keep West wild|author=Marie-Christine Bonzom|url=http://www.swissinfo.ch/eng/bernese-billionaire-works-to-keep-west-wild/31446480|work=[[Swissinfo]]|date=27 October 2011|accessdate=9 July 2015}} In 1998, he created the Wyss Foundation{{cite news|title=Another Billionaire Comes to the Defense of Africa's Elephants and Rhinos|author=Paul M.J. Suchecki|url=http://www.insidephilanthropy.com/home/2015/3/18/another-billionaire-comes-to-the-defense-of-africas-elephant.html|work=Inside Philanthropy|date=18 March 2015|accessdate=25 June 2015}} to establish and sponsor informal partnerships between non-governmental organizations and the United States government to place large swathes of land under permanent protection in the American West. By 2006, via the initial efforts of the foundation, almost {{convert|4400000|acre|km2}} of public land had been labeled as [[National Monument (United States)|national monuments]] and [[National Conservation Area|national conservation areas]].{{cite news|title=Hansjörg Wyss honored for his philanthropy|author=Jim Gerry|url=http://webcache.googleusercontent.com/search?q=cache:qH8gSvF3dG0J:https://www.aofoundation.org/Documents/aodialogue3_06.pdf+&cd=6&hl=en&ct=clnk&gl=us|work=[[AO Foundation]] |date=2006|accessdate=9 July 2015}} The organization also sponsors The Wyss Scholars Program for [[Postgraduate education|graduate-level education]] in conservation.{{cite news|title=Island student wins scholarship|url=http://www.bainbridgereview.com/community/295491161.html#|work=[[The Review (Bainbridge Island)|Bainbridge Review]]|date=7 March 2015|accessdate=25 June 2015}} The Wyss Foundation's landscape protection strategies have included assisting the purchase of mineral leases from oil and gas companies.{{cite news|title=Save the planet? Buy it|author=Jonathan Franklin|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/earth/earthnews/3349689/Save-the-planet-Buy-it.html|work=[[The Daily Telegraph]]|date=16 August 2008|accessdate=9 July 2015}}{{cite news|title=Trout Unlimited buys Rocky Mountain Front petroleum leases|author=Associated Press|url=http://billingsgazette.com/news/state-and-regional/montana/trout-unlimited-buys-rocky-mountain-front-petroleum-leases/article_4c3a694c-dcdc-547f-94fe-1cb9dafabcd4.html|work=[[Billings Gazette]]|date=12 April 2007|accessdate=17 September 2015}} Other causes the Wyss Foundation supports includes river restorations, [[Marine conservation|ocean conservation]] in Peru and Canada, anti-[[poaching]] efforts in Africa, and [[environmental journalism]].{{cite news|title=Behind one of the Nature Conservancy's largest ever forest purchases|author=Marc Gunther|url=https://www.theguardian.com/sustainable-business/2015/jan/30/behind-one-of-the-nature-conservancys-largest-ever-forest-purchases|work=[[The Guardian]]|date=30 January 2015|accessdate=25 June 2015}} In 2017, the organization announced a charitable commitment of $65 million to African Parks, a conservation NGO overseeing ten parks in seven African nations, to help create new protected areas in Africa.{{cite news |title=With Africa's Wilds Facing Growing Threats, A Billionaire Steps Up |author=Tate Williams |url=https://www.insidephilanthropy.com/home/2017/3/1/another-large-sum-from-wyss-for-land-protection-this-time-in-africa |work=[[Inside Philanthropy]] |date=1 March 2017 |accessdate=7 April 2017}} In 2010, Wyss personally gave The Nature Conservancy $35 million to purchase 310,000 acres in Montana as part of one of the largest private conservation purchases in the United States.{{cite news|title=Hansjorg Wyss: Swiss Billionaire Puts $35 Million Toward Conservation In Western Montana|author=Matthew Brown|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2010/12/14/hansjorg-wyss-swiss-billi_n_796759.html|work=[[The Huffington Post]]|date=14 December 2010|accessdate=9 July 2015}} He donated $4.25 million to [[The Trust for Public Land]] in 2013 for the purchase of oil and gas leases in [[Wyoming]] to prevent development in the Hoback Basin. In 2016, Wyss made another donation to the Trust for Public Land that resulted in the expansion of [[Saguaro National Park]] in Arizona by 300 acres, including a mile and a half of Rincon Creek.{{cite news |title=44 acres added to Saguaro National Park east |author=Elizabeth Walton |url=http://www.tucsonnewsnow.com/story/34977311/44-acres-added-to-saguaro-national-park-east |work=[[KMSB|TucsonNewsNow]] |date=23 March 2017 |accessdate=7 April 2017}} Wyss is involved with [[The Wilderness Society (United States)|The Wilderness Society]], [[Rails-to-Trails Conservancy|Rails-to-Trails]], and serves on the boards of the [[Southern Utah Wilderness Alliance]], [[Center for American Progress]], and the Grand Canyon Trust.{{cite news|title=HBS Receives $25 Million Gift for Doctoral Program|url=http://www.harbus.org/2004/hbs-receives-25-million-2892|work=The Harbus|date=25 October 2004|accessdate=25 June 2015}} In 2011, Wyss won the [[Bob Marshall (wilderness activist)|Robert Marshall Award]] from The Wilderness Society for his conservation work. In January 2015, [[Conservatism in the United States|a conservative]] U.S. news site ''[[The Daily Caller]]'' accused [[John Podesta]], who was at the time an advisor on environmental issues to the [[Presidency of Barack Obama|Obama administration]], of an ethics violation for pushing the advocacy agenda of a former employer, because he had previously received $87,000 as a consulting fee for work he did for Wyss' HJW Foundation in 2013 (that organization was later merged with the Wyss Foundation). It was noted that the Wyss Foundation had previously donated $4 million to the [[Center for American Progress]] (CAP), which Podesta founded.{{cite news|title=Obama adviser Podesta caught green-handed in major ethics violation|author=Richard Pollock|url=http://dailycaller.com/2015/01/29/obama-adviser-podesta-caught-green-handed-in-major-ethics-violation|work=[[The Daily Caller]]|date=29 January 2015|accessdate=25 June 2015}} According to the ''[[High Country News]]'', "nothing ever came of the accusations".{{cite web|title=John Podesta: Legacy maker|author=Elizabeth Shogren|url=https://www.hcn.org/issues/47.9/john-podesta-legacy-maker|work=[[High Country News]]|date=25 May 2015|accessdate=25 June 2015}} ===Support of scientific research=== In 2007, he received the Harvard Business School Alumni Achievement Award,{{cite web|url=https://www.alumni.hbs.edu/stories/Pages/story-bulletin.aspx?num=2000|title=Hansjörg Wyss, MBA 1965|date=1 January 2007|work=alumni.hbs.edu|publisher=[[Harvard Business School]]|accessdate=25 June 2015}}[http://business.inquirer.net/money/features/view/20070930-91654/Zobel_gets_highest_alumni_award_from_Harvard Zobel gets highest alumni award from Harvard] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150705210842/http://business.inquirer.net/money/features/view/20070930-91654/Zobel_gets_highest_alumni_award_from_Harvard |date=5 July 2015 }}, ''[[Philippine Daily Inquirer]]''; retrieved 15 October 2008. and in fall 2008, it was announced that Wyss donated the largest single endowment from one source in Harvard's history when he gave $125 million to found a multidisciplinary institute, the [[Wyss Institute for Biologically Inspired Engineering]] at [[Harvard University]].[http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/27073959 "Alum gives Harvard $125 million"], msnbc.com; retrieved 15 October 2008.[https://www.usatoday.com/news/education/2008-10-07-harvard-donation_N.htm Harvard alum donates record $125M], usatoday.com, 7 October 2008; retrieved 15 October 2008. In 2012-13, he announced the creation of the [[Campus Biotech]] and of its [[Wyss Center for Bio- and Neuro-engineering]] in [[Geneva]], Switzerland. In 2014, Wyss donated $120 million to the [[Swiss Federal Institute of Technology Zurich]] and the [[University of Zurich]] for the new Wyss Translational Center Zurich.{{cite news|title=Hansjörg Wyss sponsoring research|author=André Müller|url=http://www.nzz.ch/zuerich/120-millionen-dollar-fuer-zuercher-forschung-1.18443332|work=[[Neue Zürcher Zeitung]]|date=12 December 2014|accessdate=26 June 2015}} ==Political views== In 2015, Wyss publicly declared himself to be in favour of higher inheritance taxes (estate/death duty taxes) for the wealthy in [[Switzerland]].{{cite web|title=Blick: Hansjörg Wyss, der Freund der Erbschaftssteuer|url=http://www.blick.ch/news/politik/hansjoerg-wyss-der-freund-der-erbschaftssteuer-keiner-weiss-wo-er-steuern-zahlt-id3825709.html}} There has been a long-lasting rivalry between billionaire Wyss, who supports left-wing politics, and billionaire conservative [[Christoph Blocher]]. Both entered into public debates about the bilateral contracts between [[Switzerland]] and the [[European Union]] as well as the limitation of immigrants into Switzerland. Wyss, on the one hand, attempted to outline and foster the advantages of openness towards the EU and immigrants while Blocher, on the other hand, sought to highlight and emphasize the independence of Switzerland in those matters.{{cite web|title=Blick: Hansjörg Wyss und Christoph Blocher - Die Schlacht der alten Milliardäre|url=http://www.blick.ch/news/politik/wahlen2015/hansjoerg-wyss-und-christoph-blocher-die-schlacht-der-alten-milliardaere-id4095937.html}} ==Personal life== Wyss is an active hiker, skier and backpacker. He is also a hobby pilot. He lives in Wyoming,{{cite news|title=#240 Hansjoerg Wyss|url=https://www.forbes.com/profile/hansjoerg-wyss|work=[[Forbes]]|date=6 August 2015|accessdate=6 August 2015}} where he is involved in outdoor education programs and funds local efforts to conserve wildlife habitat and public lands in the Rocky Mountains.{{cite news|title=Wilderness Medicine Campus Coming to Wyoming|author=Jeanne O'Brien|url=http://www.snewsnet.com/press-release/wilderness-medicine-campus-coming-to-wyoming|work=snewsnet.com|date=5 January 2011|accessdate=18 August 2015}} In 2000, Wyss purchased the {{convert|900|acre|km2|adj=on}} Halter Ranch & Vineyard in western [[Paso Robles, California]].{{cite web|url=http://www.ocregister.com/articles/halter-596457-strupp-ranch.html|title=Swiss billionaire merges winemaking, conservation on coast|author=Faith Echtermeyer|date=8 January 2014|work=ocregister.com|publisher=[[Orange County Register]]|accessdate=25 June 2015}} The ranch includes an 1,800 acre wildlife preserve and a 281-acre vineyard producing 13 [[varietal]]s using methods that are "Sustainability in Practice" certified. The ranch hosts tours and was named "Best Vineyard Experience" by ''[[Sunset (magazine)|Sunset Magazine]]'' in 2015.{{cite news |title=At Paso Robles' Halter Ranch winery, nature and science meet |author=Sally Buffalo |url=http://www.sanluisobispo.com/living/food-drink/wine-beer/article102362507.html |work=[[The Tribune (San Luis Obispo)]] |date=16 September 2016 |accessdate=7 April 2017}} As of 2017, Wyss ranks 281 on the ''[[Forbes]]'' list of billionaires, with an estimated net worth of approximately [[United States dollar|$]]5.5 billion.{{cite web|title=Hansjoerg Wyss|url=https://www.forbes.com/billionaires/list/#version:static_search:wyss|website=[[Forbes]]|accessdate=2 January 2015}}Wilkinson, Tara Loader. [http://www.efinancialnews.com/story/2008-10-08/switzerlands-second-richest-man-makes-big-donation-to-harvard Switzerland's second richest man makes big donation to Harvard], ''[[Financial News|Wealth Bulletin]]'', 8 October 2008; retrieved 15 October 2008. He ranks number 235 on the ''[[Bloomberg News|Bloomberg]]'' list of billionaires.{{cite news|title=Bloomberg Billionaires Index|author=|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/billionaires/|work=[[Bloomberg News|Bloomberg Business]]|date=7 April 2017|accessdate=7 April 2017}} Wyss' daughter [[Amy Wyss|Amy]] also lives in Wyoming.{{cite news|title=#1044 Amy Wyss|author=|url=https://www.forbes.com/profile/amy-wyss/|work=[[Forbes]]|date=18 August 2015|accessdate=18 August 2015}} ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20110511194555/http://www.halterranch.com/Our-Story/bios/hansjorg_wyss Halter Ranch website], halterranch.com *[http://wyss.harvard.edu Wyss Institute for Biologically Inspired Engineering], wyss.harvard.edu *[http://wyssfoundation.org/ The Wyss Foundation], wyssfoundation.org {{Portal bar|Biography|Switzerland}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Wyss, Hansjorg}} [[Category:ETH Zurich alumni]] [[Category:Giving Pledgers]] [[Category:Harvard Business School alumni]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:People from Bern]] [[Category:Swiss billionaires]] [[Category:Swiss businesspeople]] [[Category:Swiss philanthropists]] [[Category:Swiss emigrants to the United States]] [[Category:1935 births]] [[Category:People from Wilson, Wyoming]]

{{Infobox University |name = Haskayne School of Business, University of Calgary |logo = [[Image:Haskayne School of Business.svg|250px]] |image = UofC Haskayne 2.png |image_size = 250px |motto = |established = 1967 |type = [[Public school (government funded)|Public]] |dean = [[Jim Dewald|Dr. Jim Dewald]] |city = [[Calgary]] |state = [[Alberta]] |country = [[Canada]] |undergrad = 2,430 |postgrad = 424 |staff= 144 |campus = |website= [http://www.haskayne.ucalgary.ca/ www.haskayne.ucalgary.ca] }}
The '''Haskayne School of Business''' is the [[University of Calgary|University of Calgary's]] [[business school]], located in [[Calgary, Alberta, Canada]]. It is named after [[Richard Haskayne|Richard F. Haskayne]], who gave one of the largest [[Financial endowment|endowments]] to a [[List of business schools in Canada|business school]] in Canada.<ref> {{cite news|url = http://www.cbc.ca/canada/calgary/story/2002/05/28/dt_5282002.html|title = Haskayne donating millions to U of C business school|publisher = [[Canadian Broadcasting Corporation|CBC]]|accessdate = 2010-08-15| date=2002-05-28}}</ref> The school offers undergraduate, masters, and PhD degrees, as well as executive education programs. Haskayne is ranked as one of the top business schools in Canada and Top 100 in the world.<ref>{{cite web|url = http://rankings.ft.com/businessschoolrankings/university-of-albertauniversity-of-calgary-haskayne|title = Financial Times Rankings|publisher = [[Financial Times]]|accessdate = 2014-11-12}}</ref>
==History== Founded as the Faculty of Management in 1967, the school was later renamed in honour of [[Richard Haskayne|Richard F. Haskayne]] in 2002. In 1986, the faculty moved into the newly constructed Scurfield Hall, which was the result of donations made by [[Ralph Thomas Scurfield|Ralph Scurfield]], his family, and [[Nu-West|Nu-West Group of Companies]].<ref>{{cite web|url = http://haskayne.ucalgary.ca/about|title = About Haskayne|publisher = [[University of Calgary]]|accessdate = 2010-08-15}}</ref>
==Programs==
===Undergraduate===
The Haskayne School of Business offers four year [[Bachelor of Commerce]] degrees in 18 concentrations, as well as degrees in Hotel and Resort Management (BHRM). BComm concentrations include [[Accounting]], [[Business Process Management]], Energy Management, Entrepreneurship & Innovation, [[Finance]], General Commerce, HR and Organizational Dynamics, [[International Business]], [[Management Information Systems]], [[Marketing]], [[Operations Management]], [[Financial adviser|Personal Financial Planning]], Petroleum and Land Management, [[Risk management|Risk Management and Insurance]], Risk Management: Insurance and Finance, [[Supply Chain Management]], [[Tourism Management]], and Tourism Management & Marketing.
A BComm [[Cooperative Education]] program is available, allowing students to gain hands-on experience in their field prior to graduating.
===MBA / Executive MBA=== The Haskayne School of Business offers full and part-time MBA programs. In 2009 the [[Financial Times]] ranked the Haskayne Executive MBA program 36th overall in the world, 4th in Canada.<ref> {{cite web|url = http://rankings.ft.com/businessschoolrankings/emba-rankings|title = Business school rankings from the Financial Times|publisher = [[Financial Times]]|accessdate = 2010-08-16}}</ref>
===Global Energy Executive MBA=== The Global Energy Executive MBA is a joint initiative of the Haskayne School of Business and IHS-[[Cambridge Energy Research Associates]]. Announced in 2010, the program was rolled out with a $1 million donation from school namesake [[Richard Haskayne]] along with local sponsorship from Calgary-based energy firms. University president [[Elizabeth Cannon]] outlined that the program will "develop responsible and responsive energy sector leaders by using an innovative teaching model that combines experiential learning and problem solving with personal leadership development."<ref>{{cite web|title=IHS and University of Calgary launch innovative Global Energy Executive MBA|url=http://energyemba.com/node/29|publisher=[[University of Calgary]]|accessdate=3 August 2011|date=12 July 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110815171024/http://energyemba.com/node/29|archivedate=15 August 2011|df=}}</ref>
The unique program consists of five interactive learning modules completed around the world. Modules are located in Calgary, the United States, and London, with another module located in either the Middle East or Asia. The 16-month program is set to launch in April 2012, with initial enrollment set at 40 students.<ref name=GEMBA>{{cite news|last=Yedlin|first=Deborah|title=U of C leads with energy MBA|url=https://calgaryherald.com/news/leads+with+energy/5077427/story.html|accessdate=28 July 2011|newspaper=Calgary Herald|date=9 July 2011}}</ref> The program curriculum will focus on energy-specific issues, such as project finance, climate change & sustainable development, and sovereign & geopolitical challenges.
==Rankings and Reputation==
===Rankings=== * In 2016, the school was ranked the #9 MBA program in the world for social and environmental impact by ''[[Corporate Knights]]'' Magazine.<ref name="Corporate Knights MBA Rankings">{{cite web |url = http://www.corporateknights.com/reports/2016-better-world-mba-ranking/2016-better-world-mba-results-14763351/ |title = 2016 Better World MBA results |publisher = [[Corporate Knights]] |accessdate = 2016-10-29 }}</ref> In the 2010 Rankings, the school's undergraduate program placed a close third nationally with a 73.4% score, and the graduate program placed second with an 83.7% score.<ref>{{cite web|title=The Results: all programs|url=http://www.corporateknights.ca/report/2010-knight-schools-survey/results-all-programs|publisher=[[Corporate Knights]]|accessdate=3 August 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110716143735/http://www.corporateknights.ca/report/2010-knight-schools-survey/results-all-programs|archivedate=16 July 2011|df=}}</ref> *In 2010, ''[[The Economist]]'' ranked Haskayne's MBA program 3rd within Canada, 43rd in North America, and 82nd worldwide.<ref>{{cite web|title=Haskayne MBA makes Top 100 in The Economist rankings|url=http://haskayne.ucalgary.ca/home/news-media/web-stories/haskayne-mba-makes-top-100-economist-rankings|publisher=[[University of Calgary]]|accessdate=3 August 2011}}</ref> *In the 2011 [[Aspen Institute]] "Beyond Grey Pinstripes" rankings, the Haskayne MBA was ranked 35th in the world's top-100 business programs (up from 51st in 2010), and #3 in Canada.<ref>{{cite web|title=Ranking: The Global 100|url=http://www.beyondgreypinstripes.org/rankings/index.cfm|publisher=The [[Aspen Institute]]|accessdate=3 August 2011}}</ref>
===Queen's University ICBC=== The Haskayne School of Business has for years dominated the [[Inter-Collegiate Business Competition (I.C.B.C)]], hosted annually by ''[[Queen's University]]''. For much of the competition's history, teams representing Haskayne have come out on top by winning first place in the majority of the competition's case study categories, which include accounting, business policy, debate, ethics, finance, human resources, marketing, and MIS, with the Haskayne School having won more than twice the competitions that the host school, and closest rival Queen's University has won. Many notable Haskayne alumni have competed as members of its ICBC teams including [[Naheed Nenshi]] and [[Gary Mar]].<ref>{{cite news|last=Pitts|first=Gordon|title=Dr. Bob, Calgary's king of competitive case study|url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/report-on-business/dr-bob-calgarys-king-of-competitive-case-study/article1382234/|accessdate=3 August 2011|newspaper=[[The Globe and Mail]]|date=9 December 2009}}</ref>
===Jeux du Commerce West=== In 2011, the Haskayne School of Business sent their first ever team to Jeux du Commerce West (JDCW), a regional business competition held in rotating host schools within Western Canada. This competition offers a wide variety of competitions ranging from sport, to debate, to academic cases and includes a major charity component. In 2011, with a half delegation, the Business Strategy case team won second place, marking the team’s entry into the competition. Following, in 2012, Haskayne sent a full delegation to the event, securing a total of 10 medals and third place as "Faculty of the Year."
==Haskayne Alumni==
===Notable Alumni=== With more than 18,000 total graduates, there are a number of notable members in the Haskayne School of Business Alumni Chapter. These include a number of corporate presidents and CEOs, political commentators, and the current Mayor of the [[City of Calgary]], 1993 Bachelor of Commerce graduate [[Naheed Nenshi]].
*[[Garrett Camp]] [[Master of Business Administration|MBA]] 2002), Co-Founder of [[Uber (company)|Uber]] and billionaire tech investor. *[[Charlie Fischer]] ([[Master of Business Administration|MBA]] 1982), President & CEO, Nexen Inc. 2001 - .<ref name=Prev_Max>{{cite web|title=Previous MAX Winners|url=http://haskayne.ucalgary.ca/haskaynealumni/previousmax|publisher=[[University of Calgary]]|accessdate=3 August 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110810063108/http://haskayne.ucalgary.ca/haskaynealumni/previousmax|archivedate=10 August 2011|df=}}</ref> *[[Kevin Foreman]], B.Comm. Haskayne, MBA [[Harvard Business School]] : millionaire entrepreneur *George Gosbee ([[Bachelor of Commerce|B.Comm.]] 1993), President, Chairman & CEO, Tristone Capital Inc.<ref name=Prev_Max /> *[[Gary Kovacs]] ([[Bachelor of Commerce|B.Comm.]] 1990 | [[Master of Business Administration|MBA]] 1999), CEO of [[Mozilla Corporation]].<ref>{{cite web|last=Prior|first=Shannon|title=Introducing our new CEO: Gary Kovacs|url=http://blog.mozilla.com/blog/2010/10/14/introducing-our-new-ceo-gary-kovacs/|publisher=[[Mozilla Corporation|Mozilla News]]|accessdate=3 August 2011}}</ref> *[[Hal Kvisle]] ([[Master of Business Administration|MBA]] 1981), President & CEO of [[TransCanada Corporation]]. 2001 - 2010,<ref>[http://www.transcanada.com/pdf/company/bios/Kvisle.pdf TransCanada Profile]{{dead link|date=December 2017}}</ref> Member of the [[Trilateral Commission]] *Mike Tims ([[Master of Business Administration|MBA]] 1973), President & CEO of MATCO Investments and Founder of Peters & Co.<ref>[https://oilandgascouncil.com/members/bio/mike-tims/vice-chairman/matco-investments-ltd]{{dead link|date=December 2017}}</ref> *[[Ezra Levant]] ([[Bachelor of Commerce|B.Comm.]] 1994), Lawyer, conservative political activist and television host. Founder and former publisher of the ''[[Western Standard]]''.{{Citation needed|date=October 2010}} *[[Naheed Nenshi]] ([[Bachelor of Commerce|B.Comm.]] 1993), Mayor of Calgary, 2010 - .,<ref>{{cite web|title=Congratulations alumnus and Mayor-elect, Naheed Nenshi|url=https://www.ucalgary.ca/alumni/stories/nenshi|publisher=[[University of Calgary]]|accessdate=3 August 2011}}</ref> followed up at [[Harvard University]] *[[W. Brett Wilson]], [[Order of Canada|OC]] ([[Master of Business Administration|MBA]] 1985), Managing Director & Chairman FirstEnergy Capital Corporation.<ref name=Prev_Max /> One of the former venture capitalists on CBC's ''[[Dragons' Den (Canada)|Dragons' Den]]'',<ref> {{cite web |url = http://www.cbc.ca/dragonsden/dragons_brett.html |title = Dragons' Den |publisher = [[Canadian Broadcasting Corporation|CBC]] |accessdate = 2011-05-29 }}</ref> Member of the [[Order of Canada]] *[[Peter Wong (banker)|Peter Wong]] ([[Bachelor of Commerce|B.Comm.]] 1973), General Manager of [[HSBC]] Group and an executive director of Hong Kong and Shanghai Banking Corporation Limited.{{Citation needed|date=October 2010}} *[[Russ Girling]] ([[Bachelor of Commerce|B.Comm.]] 1985 | [[Master of Business Administration|MBA]] 1991), President & CEO of [[TransCanada Corporation]]. 2010 - .{{citation needed|date=December 2017}}
===Management Alumni Excellence Award=== Established in the year 2000, the Management Alumni Excellence (MAX) Award recognizes the personal successes of Alumni who have made significant contributions to the Haskayne School of Business and the community at large. Of the aforementioned 18,000 alumni, 13 have been given this honor.<ref name=Prev_Max />
*2013 - Thomas Buchanan ([[Bachelor of Commerce|B.Comm.]] 1980) *2012 - Helen Wesley ([[Bachelor of Commerce|B.Comm.]] 1991) *2011 - Eva Friesen ([[Master of Business Administration|MBA]] 2000) *2010 - [[Mike Shaikh]] ([[Bachelor of Commerce|B.Comm.]] 1977) *2009 - George Gosbee ([[Bachelor of Commerce|B.Comm.]] 1993) *2008 - [[Russ Girling]] ([[Bachelor of Commerce|B.Comm.]] 1985 | [[Master of Business Administration|MBA]] 1991) *2007 - [[Ken McKinnon]] ([[Bachelor of Commerce|B.Comm.]] 1980) *2006 - David Byler ([[Bachelor of Commerce|B.Comm.]] 1978) *2005 - [[Brian Bass]] ([[Bachelor of Commerce|B.Comm.]] 1973) *2004 - Lesley Conway ([[Master of Business Administration|MBA]] 1989) *2003 - [[W. Brett Wilson]] ([[Master of Business Administration|MBA]] 1985) *2002 - [[Hal Kvisle]] ([[Master of Business Administration|MBA]] 1982) *2001 - [[Charlie Fischer]] ([[Master of Business Administration|MBA]] 1982) *2000 - Mike Tims ([[Bachelor of Commerce|B.Comm.]] 1976)
==Research Centres== *[http://haskayne.ucalgary.ca/research/research-centres/ccal Canadian Centre for Advanced Leadership in Business] *[http://haskayne.ucalgary.ca/hunter-centre Hunter Centre for Entrepreneurship and Innovation] *Centre for the Digital Economy (CDE) *Centre for Public Interest Accounting (CPIA) *Informatics Research Centre (iRC) *Risk Studies Centre (RSC) *International Resources Industries and Sustainability Centre (IRIS) *Calgary Centre for Research in Finance (CCRF) *World Tourism Education & Research Centre (WTERC)

{{Infobox politician | name = Ilan Shor | image = | image_size = | caption = | office = Mayor of [[Orhei]] | term_start = 2015 | term_end = | predecessor = | successor = | birth_name = | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1987|03|06|df=yes}} | birth_place = [[Tel Aviv]], Israel | nationality = Moldovan | residence = Moldova | occupation = Financier, banker, politician | party = [[Republican Socio-Political Movement Equality]] | years_active = | known_for = | spouse = [[Jasmin (singer)|Jasmin]] }} '''Ilan Shor''' (or '''Șor''';<ref name=whewell/> born 6 March 1987) is a Moldovan businessman and politician, who is currently under house arrest for alleged fraud after being condemned in the controversial Kroll report. Since 2015 as the elected mayor of the Moldovan city of [[Orhei]].<ref name="cec-mayors">{{cite web | url= http://www.cec.md/index.php?pag=page&id=1587&l=ro | title= Lista primarilor aleși în cadrul Alegerilor Locale Generale din 14 iunie 2015 | publisher= Comisia Electorală Centrală a Republicii Moldova | year=2015 | accessdate=15 April 2016|language=ro}}</ref> However, this is widely seen as a form of political oppression by the ruling Party. He owns several Moldovan businesses, including a company named ''Dufremol'' (Duty-free) and the [[FC Milsami]] [[association football|football]] club. In 2014, he became the chairman of the board of the Saving Bank of Moldova. He has reported in an interview that he started his own business at 13 in a mobile phone shop. He is good friends with another Moldovan millionaire, Gabi Stati.
== Personal life == Ilan Shor was born in [[Tel Aviv]], Israel on 6 March 1987, the son of Miron Shor and his wife, [[History of the Jews in Moldova|Moldovan Jews]] from [[Chișinău]] who had [[aliyah|moved to Israel]] in the late 1970s.<ref name=krasotin>{{cite news |title=Илан Шор. Биография миллиардера и мужа певицы Жасмин |trans-title=Ilan Shor. Biography of the Millionaire and husband of the singer Jasmin |url=http://www.1tvnet.ru/content/show/ilan-shor-biografiya-milliardera-i-muja-pevici-jasmin_21767.html |first=Igor |last=Krasotin |language=Russian |work=1tvnet |location=St Petersburg |date=6 September 2013 |accessdate=18 June 2015}}</ref> The family returned to Chișinău around 1990, when Shor was either two or three years old, and his father went into business in Moldova.<ref name=whewell>{{cite news |title=The Great Moldovan Bank Robbery |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/magazine-33166383 |first=Tim |last=Whewell |publisher=BBC |location=London |date=18 June 2015 |accessdate=18 June 2015}}</ref><ref name=krasotin/> His father died in 2005.<ref name=railean/> Ilan Shor has been married to the Russian singer [[Jasmin (singer)|Jasmin]] (who is 10 years older than him) since 2011.<ref name=railean>{{cite news |title=Moldova's Mysterious Magnate |url=http://www.publika.md/uite-in-ce-lux-traieste-cel-mai-tanar-milionar-moldovean--ilan-shor--si-sotia-sa--interpreta-jasmin-video_1076531.html |first=Diana |last=Railean |publisher=Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty |location=Prague |date=6 May 2015 |accessdate=18 June 2015}}</ref><ref name=publika2012>{{cite news |title=UITE în ce lux trăieşte cel mai tânăr milionar moldovean, Ilan Shor, şi soţia sa, interpreta Jasmin |trans-title=Look at the life of Moldova's youngest millionaire, Ilan Shor, and his wife, the singer Jasmin |url=http://www.publika.md/uite-in-ce-lux-traieste-cel-mai-tanar-milionar-moldovean--ilan-shor--si-sotia-sa--interpreta-jasmin-video_1076531.html |language=Romanian |work=Publika |location=Chişinău |date=14 October 2012 |accessdate=18 June 2015}}</ref> In addition to Jasmin's son from a previous marriage, they have a daughter, Margarita, who was born in 2012. Jasmin was pregnant again in 2015.<ref name=publika2012/>
== The $1 billion bank fraud scandal ==
The Kroll report claims that although the final beneficiaries are unknown, some companies that Ilan Shor has links to benefited, either directly or indirectly, from loans issued from the three banks involved in the [[Moldovan bank fraud scandal]]. On November 26, 2014 the banks went bankrupt and were later placed under special administration of the National Bank of Moldova. On 27 November, the Moldovan Government, headed by Prime Minister [[Iurie Leancă]], secretly decided to bail out the three banks with $870 million in emergency loans, covered from state reserves. This created a deficit in Moldovan public finances equivalent to an eighth of the country's GDP.
In the week preceding the 2014 Moldovan parliamentary elections, more than $750 million were extracted from the three banks between 24 and 26 November. A van belonging to Klassica Force, while transporting 12 sacks of bank files, was stolen and burned on November 27.<ref name="CNN Money">[http://money.cnn.com/2015/05/07/news/economy/moldova-stolen-billion/]</ref> Records of many transactions were deleted from the banks' computers.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.hotnews.ro/stiri-international-20075453-cine-este-ilan-shor-personajul-principal-din-raportul-krull-privind-furtul-secolului-din-republica-moldova-omul-afaceri-controleaza-banci-aeroportul-din-chisinau-televiziuni-club-fotbal.htm |title=Cine este Ilan Shor, personajul principal din raportul Kroll privind "Furtul Secolului" din Republica Moldova. Omul de afaceri controleaza banci, Aeroportul din Chisinau, televiziuni si un club de fotbal |work=HotNews.ro |date=5 May 2015 |language=Romanian}}</ref>
In March 2015 Ilan Shor was suspected by the National Anti-Corruption Center (NAC) for his work in Saving Bank. On 17 March 2015 he was questioned for 8 hours and Anti Corruption officers seized his personal property. On May 6 2015 Shor was placed under house arrest. As of 2015, Shor is allowed to move freely, after a period of house arrest. This is because he fully cooperated with the investigation. Despite this, he was allowed to register for electoral race for the mayor of city of [[Orhei]], a contest in which he won 62% of the vote on June 14 [[Moldovan local election, 2015|local government election]].<ref name=railean/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://jewishbusinessnews.com/2015/05/06/secret-audit-report-links-missing-1-billion-to-28-years-old-moldovan-businessman/|title=Did Ilan Shor Take the Missing $1 Billion From Moldovan Banks?|work=Jewish Business News}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.timesofisrael.com/israeli-born-billionaire-accused-in-moldova-scheme-to-stay-under-house-arrest/|title=Israeli-born billionaire accused in Moldova scheme to stay under house arrest|work=The Times of Israel}}</ref>
== Mayor of Orhei == After having been elected as Mayor of Orhei on the 14th June with 62% of the vote, Ilan has been busy modernising and improving the City. Notable works include building over 30km of roads for the City, which has led to a large investment in the form of a new electrical wiring factory employing 2500 workers, as well as a new asphalt factory. These were both deals that Ilan took great personal interest in. He has also introduced maternity payments which have so far reached over 500 mothers, and introduced a new method of digital submissions to the City governance, which means people can register comments and complaints, and track their progress online. This is part of his new directive on open governance.
He has invested a large amount of personal money in making Orhei a better living environment, including 1300 Lamposts with LED lights - making the streets safer and simultaneously cutting the electricity budget through replacing the existing inefficient ones. He has renovated the Ivanos Park, after 80 years of dereliction, and has poured a large amount of investment into Orhei lake - creating recreational facilities, landscaped beaches, and modern sports facilities. Ilan's Government and investment policies have paid off, with the income of the average worker rising by 300% since he took office.
